title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1871

entries.fullText:
Motto of S. Marin
Childs paper has
'On the nations
naked heart from
the coals of
living truth.'
entries.summaryText: A motto from S. Marin and a quote from Childs paper.

entries.dateText:
No. 7
DAILY
MEMORANDUM BOOK
FOR
1871
CONTAINING
Bill Book, Cash Account
ALMANAC, TIME TABLE, &c.
PUBLISHED ANNUALLY BY
FRANCIS & LOUTREL,
Steam Job Printers
AND
MANUFACTURING STATIONERS,
45 MAIDEN LANE,
NEW YORK.
entries.summaryText: A daily memorandum book for 1871 published by Francis & Loutrel in New York.

entries.fullText:
- The Dear Ann Elv??? - six
years gone 1864 died sept. 17. buried 19th
- The eldest & youngest born
thus laid away - & our dear
Father _ 8 years ago - died won
[28th]. Tuesday night - 11 O clock - buried
Saturday the 29th - three foul breaks
in eight years --
entries.summaryText: The entry talks about the death and burial of Ann Elv??? on September 17th, 1864, as well as the death and burial of the author's father eight years prior.

entries.fullText:
The dear boy died
Sunday night - 10 O clock
Dec. 4th 1870 & was buried
Tuesday P.M. 2 O clock Dec. 6th
entries.summaryText: The author writes about the death and burial of a boy on December 4th, 1870.

entries.fullText:
Went to Plymouth with
Sara & [Lyla] - Had Eugene
in *[envy/ every]*- Maggie
George down to offer
Sunday_ Roast goose
for a very lovely
dinner _ [?] [?]
[?].K. to see or hear
entries.summaryText: The author writes about spending New Year's Day in Rochester and going to Plymouth with Sara, Lyla, Eugene, Maggie, and George for a lovely dinner.

entries.fullText:
Mother, Mary & self
dined on Roast Turkey
at Sister Hannahs -
Eugene at home - very
excellent dinner.
H & Eugene and self
went to Corinthian
Hall to hear Celine
Logan - "Bright Side".
I went with her
to the Osborne House
our house - [?]
that I am
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined with her mother and sister Mary at Sister Hannah's and later went to Corinthian Hall to hear Celine Logan.

entries.fullText:
Gula went
down town with me
I bought velvetteen
for basque & over skirt
& took to Miss Larsons
called & dined at
Mary J. Callowells
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went shopping with Gula and later called on Miss Larsons before dining at Mary J. Callowells.

entries.fullText: The A.M. paper said Olive Logan was ill at Osborn House -called a short day & dined there. Dr. Moore performed surgical operation- Olive told me of Anna E Dickinson's not leaving kind word for her with Lecture Committee & asked reason - Said the world was bound to compel her to Mary Wist Dykes - but she would not she did not love him as a husband - I said then never marry him
entries.summaryText: Olive Logan was ill at Osborn House, Anna E Dickinson did not leave a kind word for her with Lecture Committee, Olive talked about not wanting to marry Mary Wist Dykes.

entries.fullText: We all intended to reach Washington in time to see & hear Anna - But could not get off in time
entries.summaryText: Could not get to Washington in time to see and hear Anna E Dickinson.

entries.fullText:
Took 9 A.M.
for Auburn.
Saw Mrs. Wright
a few hours
[?] A.M. [?]
to Skaneateles to
Cousin Anson
Lapham-find
him in usual
health and all alone
Found Ma Frost
very feeble indeed
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Auburn and visits Mrs. Wright, Cousin Anson Lapham, and Ma Frost in Skaneateles, finding the latter very feeble.

entries.fullText:
Left on P.M.
train for New
York-went to
Mrs. Murray's to
Breakfast and
then called
at J.J.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves for New York, has breakfast at Mrs. Murray's, and then visits J.J.

entries.fullText:
JANUARY
8 Sunday

Mrs. Stanton met
me & Mr. Cullen
at Tiltons - Mrs. T.
reported too ill
to see us -
we went
with J.J. to
Frank Moultons
had long talk over
J.J's retiring from
Independent &
Brooklyn Manor
Both of them asserted they
had H. B.B. phamplets
in their homes.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton, Mr. Cullen, and Susan B. Anthony met at Tiltons, but Mrs. T. was too ill to see them. They went to Frank Moultons and had a long talk about J.J.'s retiring from Independent & Brooklyn Manor. Both of them asserted they had H. B.B. phamplets in their homes.

entries.fullText:
arrived Washington
this A. M. Stopped
at 212 North Capitol
street - with Mrs
[?]. P. Griffith & daughter
- found papers full
of fiction, G. Woodhull's
memorial to Boyes.

Express package
with velveteen [basque]
& overskirt came
this evening.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Washington and stayed with Mrs. [?]. P. Griffith and daughter. She found papers full of fiction, including G. Woodhull's memorial to Boyes. She also received an express package with velveteen basque and overskirt.

entries.fullText:
National W. S. Convention
Washington D. C. -

Mrs Woodhull's
hearing before House
Judiciary Committee-
Judge Bingham. This
AM. first session
of Con. at 2 P.M.
Woodhull, Hooker,
Anthony & A. G. Riddle
made arguments before the
committee.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the National W. S. Convention in Washington D. C. and witnessed Mrs. Woodhull's hearing before the House Judiciary Committee. Woodhull, Hooker, Anthony, and A. G. Riddle made arguments before the committee.

entries.fullText:
National W. S. Conventin
Josephine S. Griffing
Splendid audience
Mrs Hazlett of
Mich. present
entries.summaryText: Attended National W. S. Convention in Washington D. C. with Josephine S. Griffing and Mrs Hazlett from Michigan. Had a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
National W. S. Con -
continued through to
day - audiences
growing larger every
session to end -
entries.summaryText: Continued attending National W. S. Convention in Washington D. C. with growing audiences every session.

entries.fullText:
Had meeting of our new team at Capitol at or mdn (?)
Took sleeper at one P.M. for New York - Victoria C. Woodhull on same car - she is very charming - utterly forgetful of difference of sex in her approach to men - her husband Col. J.H. Blood met her on Jersey Side at 6 o'clock Sunday A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a meeting with her new team at the Capitol in Washington, D.C. She then took a sleeper train to New York with Victoria C. Woodhull, who was charming and forgetful of gender differences. Woodhull's husband met her on the Jersey Side the next morning.

entries.fullText:
Took breakfast at 6.20 & was off at 7- through the snow & mud - very hard travelling
Arrived just in time - would have been too late had our train been behind
Went down to Abbey & lunched with Lydia Mott & Phebe Jones - very pleasant & old fashion cordials
Went home to Rach & ester at 10.11-
Found all back
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled through snow and mud to arrive just in time for a lunch with Lydia Mott and Phebe Jones at Abbey. She then went home to Rach and ester and found everyone back.

entries.fullText: Left Rochester at 10 A.M. Sister Gula came down in carriage with me & took Buffalo Car to Patu[??] to visit aunt Sophie McLean - a sad trip for her - over the road [???] her dues - T. R. passed this last Saturday - Nov. 12th. Took Hotel Palmer Car - dined & supper on board - around Kalamazoo, Mich at 3 A. M. - not a bed at any hotel - Grand Lodge of Masons in session - so sat on & wrote letters & took train at 7.20
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Rochester to Patu to visit her aunt Sophie McLean. She mentions T.R. passing away and having to write letters while waiting for a train in Kalamazoo.

entries.fullText: Had splendid meeting - Mr and Mrs Tradewell [???] at took [???] [???] in sleigh -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has a splendid meeting in Grand Rapids with Mr. and Mrs. Tradewell and takes a ride in a sleigh.

entries.fullText:
Left Grand Rapids
at 7:30 - arrived
Kalamazoo at 11,
and dined with
Mrs. [& Dr?] Stone -
Olympia Brown
mother called -
had delightful
visit. took train
3 P.M. - lost bolt
from Engine - got
into Chicago 9 evening
west to F. Joves -
hearty reception -
[?] Mrs. Stanton then

. every time - so help me
heaven - weak though she be.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Grand Rapids to Kalamazoo and has a delightful visit with Mrs. Stone and Olympia Brown. She then travels to Chicago and has a hearty reception at F. Joves.

entries.fullText:
Kansas City, - Mo
Mrs May Lillie Joggett
Women's Chris. Ass.
Lindell Hotel $100
Mechanics Hall
([Frank's?] is Sargent Hall)
A cordial audience
Mrs. Col. Coates,
took me in carriage
The papers a
few days after
called it "The
success of the
season" - &
this after Mrs
Livermore's
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Women's Christian Association in Kansas City and receives a cordial audience. The papers call it "The success of the season" after Mrs. Livermore's speech.

entries.fullText:
T. Bullock - Mere boy, 17 -
Liberty Hall -
Eldridge House -
Wm. Starrett met
me at Depot & took
me to dine with
them - Mrs Starrett
as bright as ever -
she introduced me -
Small audience
- The [?] [?]
entirely independent
of all local
interest - & Mrs.
Starrett bringing another
course with A.E.D.,
Gough & others -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a small audience in Lawrence, Kansas and dines with the Starretts.

entries.fullText:
Topeka Kan - $75
T. Bullock.
Union Hall -
Tefft Hotel -
Brother D. R. met
me Depot - had room
at Hotel & oh such
a house - a perfect
pig pen - A. Caldwell
just elected N.L,
Senator - L. Clarke
down & ditto D.R.
Had small audience
about $78. had
rather hard work
to speak -
- Gov Harvey
introduced me -
he endorsed W.S.
two years ago in his
message -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a small audience in Topeka, Kansas and stays at a less than desirable hotel.

entries.fullText:
T. Bullock
Farings Hall - a
very small audience
Left Topeka
at 2 A.M. with
brother D.R. arrived
at L. to breakfast -
D.R. went right to bed
I ate and staid up till
after lunch - then I
slept till 7 P.M.
Small audience -
only $27. at door -
Took only $50. though
[they?] promptly offered
me $75. Brother D.R.
pronounced it the best
argument he had ever
heard on the question
Brother D.R. gave [hay?] $10.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a small audience in Leavenworth, Kansas and only receives $50 despite being offered $75. Her brother D.R. gives $10.

entries.fullText:
Guest of Gov
Butler's.
Misty Hazy day.
Speak on Temperance
in evening
Very small audience
- only $11.
at 25 cts each -
streets are glare
of ice - had
hard work to
speak - yet all
pronounced it good.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks on Temperance to a very small audience in Lincoln, Nebraska and only receives $11.

entries.fullText:
Large gathering of
women at Clifton
House - Mrs Gaylords
& formed a W.S.
Society - with Mrs
Gov. Butler the Pres.
Left 1.15, met Mrs
Dr Traver - took
sleeping car to Kansas
City - - arrived
at 2 Tuesday A.M,
slept till 7 - then
went up & breakfasted
at the Lindell -
saw Sackett & had
$10. more pitied out of
me - making his $56 -
& he really has been of
very little service to me
took 10 A.M train Paola
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a gathering of women at Clifton House and forms a W.S. Society. She then travels to Kansas City and Paola.

entries.fullText:
Left Fort Scott at 10 A.M
Olathe, Kan
American Hotel -
Mr Burch Proprietor
Mr & Mrs Chamberlin
there -Insurance man
from Leavenworth -
not a Dozen people
at the Hall - only
$2.50 - at door -
Odd Fellows grand
encampment & protracted
meetings - 160
joined M.E. Church -
Rev, Mr & Mrs Renwich
came - Judge Fishback
absent - - hardest
bed & dirtiest room
Kansas has given
me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Olathe, Kansas and stays at the American Hotel. She attends a meeting at the Hall and notes that only a few people were present. She also mentions the Odd Fellows grand encampment and protracted meetings. She comments on the poor quality of her room.

entries.fullText:
no meeting - Protracted
meetings in May -
so took 3 A.M. train
for Kansas City & arrived
at Leavenworth at
8:40 - found warm
welcome - called
on Mrs Terry - & from
D.R.'s office window
saw the Caldwell procession -
the Senator of U.S.
Dan brot home
splendid turkey -
Mr. Shurman, English
editor of Conservatism,
called - but I was in
bed - - Little Maud [?]
the woman because I failed to
call on her W. W. T.

sent $8. to the Revolution
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Kansas City and Leavenworth, meets with Mrs. Terry and sees the Caldwell procession. She also receives a visit from Mr. Shurman and sends $8 to the Revolution.

entries.fullText:
no meeting by
counsel P. B. Taylor -
Left Leavenworth at
2:40 P.M. for Kansas
City to take 11.15 Omaha
train - no crossing
the river Saturday nights
- stopped at Sheridan Hotel
A Col. Jeffries - whom
I met on train going to
Fort Scott & told me of
'Corn Sweat' to cure
rheumatism - very publicly
Suckett told me he
was a river gambler -
Suckett [hurry?] one for me
to give him my lecture business
next year - but I
refused to totally -
called on Mrs Col. [Curtis?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Leavenworth for Kansas City and then Wyandotte. She meets with Col. Jeffries and Suckett, who asks for her lecture business, but she refuses. She also calls on Mrs. Col. [Curtis?].

entries.fullText:
Waited on Iowa side
For Burlington & Mo. River
Rock Island & Great N.
Western trains to arrive
- So four Eastern Roads
enter into Omaha
at same hour - all
crossed river on
temporary bridge in
transfer cars - at noon -
Found good quarters
at Wyoming Hotel -
Building a $2.500.000
bridge - have to mine
down 60 & 70 feet to find
rock bottom - take two
years to finish it.
Crossed just where
G.F. Trains City Lots -
they say he has lost his
hold on them entirely -
entries.summaryText: Describes the author's journey to Omaha, Nebraska, and the construction of a new bridge.

entries.fullText:
Mr. M.G. McKoon &
wife & [Judge] Mr Evans
called for me to go
about City - visited
one school & talked to
the schools - two Miss
McKoons teachers, &
Miss Balentine of
Gates-Monroe Co.
another -
tried to take a sleep
after dinner but no go
too noisy -
Mrs Mary E. Peabody
Mrs Helen R. McKoon
Had fine audience
- Odd Fellows made money -
entries.summaryText: Describes the author's visit to schools in Omaha, Nebraska, and attending a speaking engagement with the Odd Fellows organization.

entries.fullText:
Ms Amelia Bloomer
Fine audience
$40 - Had
Pleasant visit with
Ms Bloomer - &
M.B. said made
a strong argument-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a fine audience in Council Bluff and had a pleasant visit with Ms Amelia Bloomer who made a strong argument.

entries.fullText:
Left Council
Bluffs at 4 P.M.
for Cedar Rapids
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Council Bluffs at 4 P.M. for Cedar Rapids.

entries.fullText:
Mr. Eastman
Chair - Lecture 6am-
Stouffers Hotel
Had packed
House - & made
good speech
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mr. Eastman's lecture in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

entries.fullText:
M.B.C. True -
Left Cedar Rapids
at 7.30 - arrived
station and
took sleigh to Toledo
Had pleasant
home at M -
and fine audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her trip from Cedar Rapids to Toledo, Iowa and her lecture at M.B.C. True's home.

entries.fullText:
Left Toledo for
Iowa - N. Western R.R.
Went to Junction & thence
to Des Moisnes - Took
Omnibus to Mrs
Savory's - Found
both Mr & Mrs S. out
for the evening - but
soon they returned
& gave me a
most hearty
welcome - right
royal are they -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Toledo to Des Moisnes, Iowa and is warmly welcomed by Mr. and Mrs. Savory.

entries.fullText:
James C. Savorys
Des Moisnes
Had pleasant
day - she that was
Lizzie Boynton - &
her her husband
Mr Harbert Lawyer
dined at the Savory's
also another lady & Gentle-
man special friends
then, we called at
their house in evening
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a pleasant day with friends, including Lizzie Boynton and Mr. Harbert Lawyer, at the Savory's house in Des Moisnes.

entries.fullText:
Court House -
Mrs James C. Savery
~ Annie Savery
Mrs. M. B. Haven secy -
Mrs. Martha C. Callanan - Com -
Mrs Sharman- Pres.
James Callanan of Albay
splendid audience
and Mr Tanay said
it was the happiest
circumstance for me -
that I had followed
Lucy Stone & that she
was so much less than
people had anticipated - & I so
much stronger than he had
expected.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Court House in Des Moisnes Iowa, with Mrs. James C. Savery, Annie Savery, Mrs. M. B. Haven, Mrs. Martha C. Callanan, Mrs. Sharman, James Callanan of Albay, and Mr. Tanay in attendance. Mr. Tanay said it was a happy circumstance that Susan had followed Lucy Stone and that she was stronger than expected.

entries.fullText:
Met W. S. women
at Y. M. A. rooms at
10 A. M. talked to them
about working to their
elections of legislation.
Dined at Savoy
House with M [?]
Savoy - left at
645 - Rock Island Hotel
at 11.30 - slept on
hardest kind of bed -

Met Wm. L. Carington
of West Winstead st
who said he would
get up lecture them from
awns [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with W. S. women at Y. M. A. rooms and talks to them about working towards their elections of legislation. She dines at Savoy House with M [?] and later meets with Wm. L. Carington of West Winstead st who said he would get up lecture them from awns [?].

entries.fullText:
Mrs. D. R. Beck -
Met Cousin Joseph
Anthony in depot
Said Uncle John had
come to Sterling for first
time this winter & was
somewhere selecting
lumber[?]. Went straight
to Becks & uncle J. did
not call - Worried &
worried about not going
& finding him
Almost felt that
I had neglected my
own dear Father
- but I could not
get track of him again
until after he had left town
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mrs. D. R. Beck and Cousin Joseph Anthony in Sterling, Illinois. Uncle John is in town for the first time this winter and is selecting lumber. Susan goes to Beck's house but Uncle John does not call. She worries about not finding him and feels like she neglected her own father.

entries.fullText:
W.W. Norton
Left Sterling 12
arrived Junction 3 P.M.
- dinner Junction House -
left J. at 3.45 - arrived
Dundee 7.15 - Mr
Henry C. Edwards
took me to his house dressed,
tea & to Congregational
Church at 8 - Rev Mr
Hill the Pastor presented
me - fine audience
- dressed, lunched & Mr
Edwards took me back
to West Elgin to 12.30
- alas no train till 4.45-
so sat bolt upright in
Depot - four hours - actually
tried lying on floor -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Sterling and arrives in Dundee, Illinois. She has dinner at Junction House and arrives at Mr. Henry C. Edwards' house. She attends the Congregational Church where she is presented by Rev Mr Hill. She spends time with Mr. Edwards and returns to West Elgin but has to wait four hours for the next train.

entries.fullText:
All this lost nights
sleep - laboring under
the mistake that I
must be at the Central
R.R. Chicago at 9.20 to get to
Watseka to speak
to night - Chicago 7-
Judge Bradwell not in
official - [?] found
mistake until arrived
at McCurdy House - boy
said it is tomorrow night -
went strait to bed at
3.30 & slept tell 5.20 -
too, too bad - did
so want to spend the
day in Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about losing sleep and making a mistake about the date of her speaking engagement in Watseka, Illinois. She wanted to spend the day in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
called for me to go with
her - but postponed
until after lecture -
good audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a good audience at her speaking engagement in Watseka, Illinois and plans to go with someone after the lecture.

entries.fullText:
Continued run
of callers all
day - Mrs Betsey
Hawks - formerly of
Genesee Co. N. York
came also -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Dodge's and receives many visitors, including Mrs. Betsey Hawks from Genesee County, New York.

entries.fullText:
Left Watseka
on Toledo & Wabash
R.R. to Lafayette thence
to Dayton - just
saw A.J. Boyer
& engaged to go
back & speak
there the 24th -
his wife very ill
with Consumption
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Watseka to Dayton, stopping in Lafayette, and arranges to speak there on the 24th. She sees A.J. Boyer, who tells her his wife is very ill with consumption.

entries.fullText:
Charles W. Clemanent
Antioch College -
Stopped the Rev.
William Hosmers -
President Antioch College -
Mrs Hosmer one of the
most hospitable women
Had fine audience
in College Chapel
& the Dr. said 'I have
heard all the woman
suffrage women lecture,
but, Miss Anthony, I have
to night listened to an
argument for the first time -
a compliment above all
compliments coming from
so aged & conservative a
minister
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Antioch College and receives a compliment from Rev. William Hosmers.

entries.fullText:
Ms E. D. Stewart
Mrs. M. C. Allison
sister of Mrs. Starrett
Xenia - Ohio - met
me at Depot & made me
promise to visit her after
Antioch -
Small meeting
at Springfield out of pocket -
Stopped at Hotel - an
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a small meeting in Springfield and meets with Ms E. D. Stewart and Mrs. M. C. Allison.

entries.dateText:
February
23 Thursday
4 miles from Hema (?)
(?) me at Hema Point (?)
Spoke in e(?) (?)
and Mrs. Allison of
Henin (?) came over
to Millerpore and
I went home with
them-
Many bright & from (?)
(?) young (?) colored girls
in this school-
entries.fullText:
February
23 Thursday
4 miles from Hema (?)
(?) me at Hema Point (?)
Spoke in e(?) (?)
and Mrs. Allison of
Henin (?) came over
to Millerpore and
I went home with
them-
Many bright & from (?)
(?) young (?) colored girls
in this school-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at an event and visited a school with Mrs. Allison in Millerpore.

entries.dateText:
February
24 Friday
Dayton Ohio
Huston Hall
Phillip House
Pleasant visit with
Mrs. Allison-talked with
Mrs. Starret (?) of Lawrence
Kansas - Took them
to Dayton-Make to
very small audience-
between 30 & 40 dollars
out of pocket-

Learned of Mr. Roger
or asked him to loan
of M(?) took fair
for Sulern (?) _ Ohio at
H.P.M (?) Western
(?) the (?) & (?)
entries.fullText:
February
24 Friday
Dayton Ohio
Huston Hall
Phillip House
Pleasant visit with
Mrs. Allison-talked with
Mrs. Starret (?) of Lawrence
Kansas - Took them
to Dayton-Make to
very small audience-
between 30 & 40 dollars
out of pocket-

Learned of Mr. Roger
or asked him to loan
of M(?) took fair
for Sulern (?) _ Ohio at
H.P.M (?) Western
(?) the (?) & (?)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a pleasant visit with Mrs. Allison and spoke to a small audience in Dayton, Ohio. She also learned of Mr. Roger and took a fair to Sulern, Ohio.

entries.fullText:
reached Salem
about 11 A.M. -
Parker Pillsbury has
misunderstood my
letters - hence notice
of Lecture had been
recalled - but little bills
were at once printed & a
fine audience we had
& all delighted-
Marnis Robinson
Barnaby
And P.P. pronounced
the Lecture good-the
Hon. Mr. Catell introduced
the man who reported favorably
on W.S. in 1859 in O. legislature
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached Salem, Ohio and gave a lecture that was well received despite a recall notice due to a misunderstanding with Parker Pillsbury. Hon. Mr. Catell introduced a man who reported favorably on W.S. in 1859 in O. legislature.

entries.fullText:
Went to hear P.P.'s
last Sunday lecture- It
was just like him - splendid
- full house - Mr Robbinson
presented resolutions -of
appreciation & thanks
Mr. Pillsbury responded
& there were many moist
eyes, among men too -all
moved to tears-
Mrs Robinson had
large party at her house
this P.M. - but I was
obliged to take hurried
lunch & P.P. went with
me to Depot at 2 P.M.
Arrived at Crestline
about 8 P.M. - took
supper & went to dirtiest
room & bed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended Parker Pillsbury's lecture and witnessed Mr. Robbinson present resolutions of appreciation and thanks. Mrs. Robinson hosted a party and Susan had to leave early to catch a train with Parker Pillsbury.

entries.fullText:
Left my hard &
not so clean bed
& room at Crestline
at 10 & arrived at
Columbus at 1 - P.M.
stopped Neil House_
Head the Representative
Hall packed
nearly every member both
houses present - made
good argument on 14 & 15 Am't
Ms. R.S.A. Janney
Ms. Elizabeth Coit
Mrs. Coit the best -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Crestline and arrived in Columbus, Ohio. She stopped at Neil House and made a good argument on 14 & 15 Am't. She mentions Ms. R.S.A. Janney, Ms. Elizabeth Coit, and Mrs. Coit.

entries.fullText:
Left Columbus O. at
11-10 - arrived at
Monroeville Lake Shore R.R. - 3 P.M.
nice dinner - and
on board Mich. South.
R.R. & lo there sat
Mrs. Stanton all
curled up - gray curls
sticking out - fast asleep -
hard to part at Toledo -
she to Detroit, I to Jackson
arrived at J. at 11.30 -
Hibbard House - slept
till 5 then up & off
again - tough, tough
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Columbus and arrived at Monroeville Lake Shore R.R. She saw Mrs. Stanton on board Mich. South. R.R. and it was hard to part at Toledo. She arrived at Jackson and stayed at Hibbard House.

entries.fullText:
Took cars from
Jackson at 6 A.M. &
arrived Lansing 8 - &
went to Mrs. D.L. Case
- met warm welcome -
Large meetings &
earnest - made
argument on 14th & 15th
amendments in evening-
Mrs. Wheaton spoke in
Legislative Hall against
W. S.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Jackson to Lansing, Michigan, meets with Mrs. D.L. Case, attends large meetings, and argues about the 14th and 15th amendments. Mrs. Wheaton spoke against W.S. in Legislative Hall.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Hazzlett did
not [reach[ come into Convention
until this A.M but
to hear Mrs. Wheaton
last night - she
came in with cold
water on 14th Amd't
road to freedom her
[feet?] echo of Republicanism
Splendid discussion
several men took
part in evening
Mrs Lothrope & Mrs
[Haight?] spoke in
(?) (?) (?)
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Hazzlett arrives at the convention in Lansing, Michigan. Mrs. Wheaton spoke about the 14th amendment. Mrs. Lothrope and Mrs. Haight spoke in the evening.

entries.fullText:
All this lost nights
sleep - laboring under
the mistake that I
must be at Ill Central
R.R. Chicago at 9.20 to get to
Watseka to speak
to night. Chicago 7-
Judge Bradwell not in
office. Never found
mistake until arrived
at McCurdy House - boy
said it is tomorrow night -
went strait to bed at
3.30- & slept till 5.20-
Too, too bad - did
so want to spend the
day in Chicago.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her lost night's sleep and the mistake she made about the date of her lecture in Watseka. She also mentions her desire to spend the day in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
called for me to go with
her - but postponed
until after lecture-
Good audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a good audience at her lecture in Watseka and a postponed invitation from Mrs. Dodge.

entries.fullText:
Continual run
of callers all
day - Ms Betsey
Hawkes - formerly of
Genesee B. N. Josh
came also -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a busy day with many visitors including Ms Betsey Hawkes and B. N. Josh.

entries.fullText:
Left Watseka
on Toledo & Western
R.R. to [L?] then
to Dayton - just
saw A. J. Boyer
+ engaged to go
back & speak
there the 24th
his wife very ill
with Consumption
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Watseka and traveled to Dayton where she saw A. J. Boyer and agreed to speak there on the 24th. Boyer's wife was very ill with consumption.

entries.fullText:
Stopped the Rev.
William Hosmers -
President Antioch College -
Mrs Hosmer one of the
most hospitable woman
Had fine audience
in College Chapel -
& the Dr. - said "I have
heard all the womn
suffrage movement lectures,
but, Miss Anthony, I have
to night listened to an
argument for the first time -
a complement above all
complements coming from
so aged & conservative a
minister
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped the Rev. William Hosmers, President of Antioch College, and had a fine audience in College Chapel. The Dr. complimented her argument for the women's suffrage movement.

entries.fullText:
Small meeting
at Springfield out of pocket -
Staffed at Hotel - [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a small meeting in Springfield and stayed at a hotel.

entries.dateText:
FEBRUARY
23 Thursday

Wilberforce [illegible] 4 miles from Henin
Pres. Paine Prof. Jackson
Met me at Henin depot
[Shake] in envy - Mr. and Mrs. Allicou of Henin came over
to Wilberforce and [P ment] home with
[illegible].
May bright and from [illegible] young Colored girls
in this school.
entries.fullText:
Wilberforce [illegible] 4 miles from Henin
Pres. Paine Prof. Jackson
Met me at Henin depot
[Shake] in envy - Mr. and Mrs. Allicou of Henin came over
to Wilberforce and [P ment] home with
[illegible].
May bright and from [illegible] young Colored girls
in this school.
entries.summaryText: Met with Pres. Paine and Prof. Jackson in Wilberforce. Visited with Mr. and Mrs. Allicou of Henin. Saw young Colored girls in school.

entries.dateText:
FEBRUARY
24. Friday

Dayton Ohio
Huston Hart
Philbys House

Pleasant visit with
Mrs. Allison - talking over
Mrs. Starch of Laurence
Kansas - Took Jim to Dayton -Spoke to
very small audience -
between 30 & 40 dollars
out of Pocket.
Loaned of Mr Boyer
or asked him to loan
at [illegible]. Took [Fair]
for Salem Ohio at
H.P. m Grant Western
[R.be] through Chicago & Fort [Morgan]
entries.fullText:
Dayton Ohio
Huston Hart
Philbys House

Pleasant visit with
Mrs. Allison - talking over
Mrs. Starch of Laurence
Kansas - Took Jim to Dayton -Spoke to
very small audience -
between 30 & 40 dollars
out of Pocket.
Loaned of Mr Boyer
or asked him to loan
at [illegible]. Took [Fair]
for Salem Ohio at
H.P. m Grant Western
[R.be] through Chicago & Fort [Morgan]
entries.summaryText: Visited with Mrs. Allison and discussed Mrs. Starch of Laurence, Kansas. Spoke to a small audience in Dayton and spent between 30 & 40 dollars out of pocket. Loaned money from Mr Boyer. Took a train to Salem Ohio through Chicago and Fort Morgan.

entries.fullText:
reached Salem
about 11 A.M. -
Parker Pillsbury has
misunderstood my
letters - hence notice
of Lecture had been
recalled - But little bills
were at once printed & a
fine audience we had
& all delighted -
Marius Robinson Barnaby
and P.P. pronounced
the Lecture good - the Hon. Mr. Cotell introduced
the man who reported favorably on [?]. [?]. in 1859 in O. Legislature
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached Salem, Ohio and gave a lecture that was well received by the audience. Parker Pillsbury misunderstood her letters, but the notice of the lecture was recalled and little bills were printed. Marius Robinson, Barnaby, and P.P. pronounced the lecture good. The Hon. Mr. Cotell introduced the man who reported favorably on [?]. [?]. in 1859 in O. Legislature.

entries.fullText:
Went to hear P.P.'s
last Sunday lecture - it
was just like him - splendid
- full house - Mr. Robbinson
presented resolutions - of
appreciation and thanks
Mr. Pillsbury responded
& there were many moist
eyes, among men too - all
reduced to tears -
Mrs Robinson had
large party at her house
this P.M. - but I was
obliged to take hurried
lunch and P.P went with
me to Depot at 2 P. M.
Arrived at Crestline
about 8 P.M. - took
supper & went to dirtiest
room I had
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended Parker Pillsbury's last Sunday lecture, which was well received by the audience. Mr. Robbinson presented resolutions of appreciation and thanks, and Mr. Pillsbury responded. Mrs. Robinson had a large party at her house, but Susan B. Anthony was obliged to take a hurried lunch and leave. She arrived at Crestline, took supper, and went to the dirtiest room she had.

entries.fullText:
Left my hard &
not so clean bed
& room at Crestline
at 10 and arrived at
Columbus at 1 - P.M.
Stopped Neil House.
Had the Representative
Hall packed
nearly every member both
houses present - made
good argument as on [?] [?] Am't
Mrs. R.SA. Jannery
Mrs. Elizabeth Coit
Mrs. Coit the best.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Crestline and arrived in Columbus, where she stayed at the Neil House. She had a good argument at the Representative Hall and met with Mrs. R.SA. Jannery and Mrs. Elizabeth Coit.

entries.fullText:
Left Columbus O, at
11-16 - arrived at
Monroeville (Lake Shore R.R.) - 3 P.M.
nice dinner - and
on board Mich. South
R.R. and lo there sat
Mrs Stanton all
curled up - gray curls
sticking out - fast sleep -
- had to part at Toledo -
she to Detroit. I to Jackson
arrived at J. at 11:30 -
Hibbard House - slept
till 5 then up & off
again - tough tough.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Columbus and arrived in Monroeville, where she had a nice dinner. She met with Mrs. Stanton on the train, but they had to part ways in Toledo. Susan arrived in Jackson and stayed at the Hibbard House.

entries.fullText:
Took cars from
Jackson at 6 A.M. &
arrived Lansing 8 - &
went to Mrs. D. L. Case.
- met warm welcome -
Large meetings &
earnest - made
argument on 14th & 15th
amendments in evening
Mrs. Wheaton spoke in
Legislative Hall against
W. S.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Lansing, Michigan, meets with Mrs. D. L. Case, attends large meetings and makes arguments on 14th and 15th amendments. Mrs. Wheaton spoke against W. S. in Legislative Hall.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Hazzlett did
not [reach] come into Convention
until this A.M. but
to hear Mrs. Wheaton
last night. - She
came in with cold
water on 14th Amd't
road to freedom - her
feet echo of Republicanism
Splendid discussion.
several men took
part in evening.
Mrs. Lufhouse & Mrs.
Hazlett spoke in
reprise ??
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Hazzlett arrives at the convention in Lansing, Michigan. Mrs. Wheaton spoke about the 14th Amendment and road to freedom. Mrs. Lufhouse and Mrs. Hazlett spoke in reprise.

entries.fullText: Mrs Stanton spoke before the Lyceum this evening. Mrs [?] the train Mrs S. gave her presentation & people [?]. [?] [?] is Mrs Livermore
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton spoke before the Lyceum in Lansing, Michigan and Mrs S. gave her presentation.

entries.dateText:
March
6 Monday
Romeo - Mich -
Ridgeway Station D&M R.R.
entries.cityOrState:
Romeo - Mich -
Ridgeway Station D&M R.R.
entries.fullText: Left Ann Arbor at 8 - arrived Detroit & stopped there till 7, then to Ridgeway & on short R.R. to Romeo. Everything all ready - cup of tea at Mrs McCoy's - & thence to Hall - made a good speech - The Congregational minister called - said Mrs. Stanton's speech needed mine to complete it —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Romeo, Michigan and gave a speech at the Hall. The Congregational minister called and said Mrs. Stanton's speech needed hers to complete it.

entries.fullText:
Took early train and went up to Huron - having given them this eve's lecture - but no arrangement made - called on Mrs.
then went to Hotel & slept.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took an early train to Huron, gave a lecture, called on Mrs., and then went to a hotel to sleep.

entries.fullText: Took train early but had long delay & at Junction. took car into Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took an early train from Huron Mich, but had a long delay at Junction and eventually took a car into Chicago.

entries.fullText:
arrived at Mrs. Jones Chicago
and found Mrs.
Stanton already
their. Had full talk
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and met with Mrs. Jones and Mrs. Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Chicago — the
Cook County W. S.
Council Meeting
Farwell Hall
Good meetings
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the Cook County W.S. Council Meeting at Farwell Hall in Chicago and reported that the meetings were good.

entries.fullText:
Matinee in Park
First woman
Sufferage matinee -
Music, short speeches
& the entertainment
Was delightful
A fine audience
entries.summaryText: Attended a suffrage matinee in Chicago's Cook County Park with music, short speeches, and entertainment.

entries.fullText:
Self called at Mrs. S.
H. Gay’s. Then I
Went to Robert Collyer’s
To dine - thence
To 206 Erie st. To
Call on cousins
Joseph & Lydia Safham
& then back to Mrs.
Jone’s. Tired out
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. S. H. Gay and Robert Collyer, then went to visit cousins Joseph and Lydia Safham before returning to Mrs. Jone's. Felt tired.

entries.fullText:
Spent the day
at Mrs Jones-
Mrs Stanton left
for home at 4.30
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Mrs Jones' in Chicago with Mrs Stanton who left for home at 4.30.

geographicalLocations: Aunt Anna Eliza Dickinson 113 South Green St
entries.fullText:
Spent day & night
with Aunt Anna Eliza
Dickinson 113 South
Green St - general
& genuine chat on
every thing & every body
Got Life Insurance
for $5,000 - in 'National
Life Co. of Chicago -
paid $21. - for first
payment -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day and night with Aunt Anna Eliza Dickinson in Chicago, had a general and genuine chat on everything and every body, and got life insurance for $5,000 in 'National Life Co. of Chicago' by paying $21 for the first payment.

entries.fullText:
Spent A.M. Carters
office writing then
called Mrs. Fernado [gone?]
& thence to Depot -
arrived Earlville
8 P.M. - Found
Cousin Susan moved
to village in nice little
cottage & boarding there,.
Rev. M. Barnes & wife
Universalist minister -
Found warm welcome
as I always do with my
Father's dear Sisters daughter
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Chicago to Earlville, visits Mrs. Fernado and arrives at Cousin Susan's new home where she is welcomed by Rev. M. Barnes and his wife.

entries.fullText:
Cousin & self
called Grover's
Got immense
letter (six letter Heads)
from Mrs J.B. Hooker
on the work of National
Committee & specifically
on the war against
Mrs V. C. Woodhull
It is the same old
game - to cut off woman
for offenses almost every
man is guilty of - I will
not listen to a word of it
but work with all women
as we do with all men
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Mrs J.B. Hooker regarding the work of the National Committee and the war against Mrs V. C. Woodhull, but refuses to listen to any attempts to cut off women for offenses that almost every man is guilty of.

entries.fullText:
Spent A.M. thinking &
noting points - & taking
a sleep - heavy load
from fish dinner yesterday -
at 3.30 P.M.
found M. E. Church
packed full & made
a pretty fair speech (after
I got under sail) on the
duty of woman to possess
the power to control
the circumstance of
herself & children,
in the home & outside
- Mr & Mrs A.J. Grover
spent the evening at Cousin
Susan's with me - all
the rest went to Church
Gave him a plain talk,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a speech at the M. E. Church in Earlville, Illinois on the duty of women to control their own circumstances.

entries.fullText:
Left Earlville A.M.
stopped Mendota to
Express train - called on
Mrs [J.?] E. Smith- found
all packed up - moving to
Vinton Iowa - 9 miles from
Vinton by carriage-
Mr Rolf
Universalist minister
formerly Earlville
me me Depot
& took me to
his house
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Earlville and visited Mrs. [J.?] E. Smith in Mendota before continuing on to Mount Pleasant, where she was taken to the home of Mr. Rolf, a Universalist minister.

entries.fullText: Small audience but very good
entries.summaryText: Small audience but very good

entries.fullText: Took train 10.45 P.M. for Plattsmouth arrived at P. 10 A.M. had fine audience & engaged for next [stop?]
entries.summaryText: Took train to Plattsmouth, had fine audience and engaged for next stop

entries.fullText:
P.M. Strong-
Small meeting
Stopped at Brooks
Hotel-
Got Telegram from
W. L. Wilkins Sioux
City, asking why I was
not there Tues. 21st-
answered because I did
not know they expected
me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a small meeting in Plattsmouth, Neb. and received a telegram from W. L. Wilkins in Sioux City.

entries.fullText:
[J. Renner- Editor]
W.P . Roberts- Vice Pres.
Mrs. Dr. J. H. Avery-
Arrived Mr [?]
at 9 A.M.,
Had fine audience
Judge Mason asked
questions - he had
decided Negroes not
right to be jurors
by 14th amendment -
Dr. Smith took
photograph - passably
good
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a fine audience in Nebraska City and Judge Mason asked questions about the 14th amendment and the right of Negroes to be jurors.

entries.fullText: Had pleasant day at Dr Mays Mr & Mrs Wm Miller boarders at Mr Mays - Left at 3 P.M. for Burlington a second Telegram from Sioux City about failure to go there - never received his letter saying he accepted the night -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a pleasant day at Dr Mays with Mr & Mrs Wm Miller as boarders. She left for Burlington but received a second telegram from Sioux City about failure to go there.

entries.fullText: Burlington Arrived at 8 A.M. took breakfast and dinner at hotel Mr Huston set carriage for me to go to [Mr?] Theodore W. [Baileycity?] - where I found delightful entertainment house on the Bluff in north part of City -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Burlington and had breakfast and dinner at a hotel. She was set up with a carriage to go to Mr Theodore W. Baileycity where she found delightful entertainment at a house on the Bluff in the north part of the city.

entries.fullText:
[Stayed?] with Ellie &
J.W. Barhydt -
Mrs. Darwin
Teacher in Baptist College -
Letter from sister Mary
telling of sudden death of
Dr Henry McLeans wife -
Aaron went down funeral
Gula did not - went to Maggie
leaving mother & Mary & girl by
[?] all alone in house &
lonesome enough -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed with Ellie and J.W. Barhydt in Burlington, Iowa. She received a letter from her sister Mary informing her of the sudden death of Dr Henry McLeans wife. Aaron went to the funeral but Gula did not.

entries.fullText:
John Ackley
Burtis House
John T. Smits
introduced me to a
fine audience -
(Left on 7.45 [?]
A.M. - for Syracuse)
Clerk gave me
note left by G. F. Train
who passed through early last
A.M. for Freeport M -
saying great disappointment
at Sioux City - that he always
spoke of me in his meeting
& that I should of him when I
had more faith in him - & more [pluck?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was introduced to a fine audience by John T. Smits in Davenport, Iowa. She received a note from G. F. Train who expressed disappointment at Sioux City and mentioned that he always spoke of her in his meetings.

people: Mr and Mrs Oliver J. Bailey
entries.fullText: Stopped at Simmon Hotel - Mr and Mrs Oliver J. Bailey called want me next year
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Simmon Hotel in Sycamore, Illinois. Mr. and Mrs. Oliver J. Bailey called and want her next year.

entries.fullText: J. P. Norman met me at Depot & said I had better not attempt to speak - that there were two Church converts & one sociable that evening & not a ghost of a chance for an audience - so I rushed into train & went on to Galena - arrived at 6.09 - afterwards learned that a great many were greatly disappointed - & were told that I was seen in Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met J. P. Norman at the Depot in Rockford, Illinois. Norman advised her not to speak as there were only two Church converts and one sociable that evening. Anthony rushed into the train and went on to Galena. Later, she learned that many were disappointed and were told that she was seen in Chicago.

entries.fullText: M. M. Miller stopped with Mrs Sarrah Coates Harris, wife of Capt D. L. Harris, introduced by Mr Bird small audience. Left Galena at 5.28 Saturday A. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Galena, Illinois and stays with Mrs. Sarrah Coates Harris, meeting with a small audience before leaving the next day.

entries.fullText: Chamberlain Belvidere Ill - Wm W. Fuller stopped with Mrs L. H. Brown - introduced by Mr John Rollins.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Ripon, Wisconsin and Belvidere, Illinois, staying with Mrs. L. H. Brown and meeting with Chamberlain and Wm W. Fuller, introduced by Mr. John Rollins.

entries.fullText:
at Mrs L.K. Brown
went Presbyterian
Church - Rev Mr. D. R.
Eddy - about future
state - Collective
for Education
minister supposed
all knew its object
to educate poor
young man for ministry
left out the 'pious'
entries.summaryText: Attended Presbyterian Church in Belvidere, Illinois with Mrs L.K. Brown and heard Rev Mr. D. R. Eddy speak about the future state of Collective for Education and the education of poor young men for ministry.

entries.fullText:
[Mr?] F. McGuire
Went down to
Junction - thence west
to Clinton - had
a fine audience
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Junction to Clinton, Iowa with Mr? F. McGuire and had a fine audience.

entries.fullText: Cousin E. met me Depot, took me out to his farm a full [mile] square mile had pleasant time & big load went into town in evening - Had large audience - and took train at 12 Oclock east to Dixon - then slept till 10 Wednesday A.M. - Cold room & hard bed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Cousin E. in Morrison Ill and has a pleasant time before taking a train to Dixon.

entries.fullText: Took Ill. Central at 11 to Mendota then C.B.& Q. to Princeton - Miss Lovejoy - daughter of Owen Lovejoy - met me Depot & made me most welcome - and comfortable - plenty of nice fruit & cream etc
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Princeton Ill and is welcomed by Miss Lovejoy and plenty of nice fruit and cream.

entries.fullText:
Gave second
lecture this eve
on 14 & 15 amendment.
Mrs Patterson
owns the Hall & wants
me to come next winter.
Slept at Mrs Owens
until 3 A.M. then
her son took me to
Depot - took
sleeping car into
Chicago -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture on the 14th and 15th amendment in Princeton, Illinois. She stayed at Mrs. Owens' house and took a sleeping car to Chicago.

entries.fullText:
Jas. R. Caanahan
Left Chicago 9 A.M.
arrived 3.30 P.M. and
took dinner, slept and
spoke two hours - then
took train back to
Chicago at 11 P.M.
John Brokenbraugh &
wife called -
Thomas Atkinson
Oxford - Benton Co. Indiana
rode 20 miles to see
& hear me - a Quaker
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Lafayette, Indiana and spoke for two hours. She also met with several people including John Brokenbraugh and Thomas Atkinson who rode 20 miles to see her speak.

entries.fullText:
Woman Suffrage Matinee -
Arrived Chicago
at 8 A.M. Went
to Mrs Jones 810 Prince
Avenue -
Had small but
good audience -
made my Power
of the Ballot - Mr
Jones & all men
surprized at my
argument & said
it was worthy the
largest house Chicago
could give
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and gave a speech on Woman Suffrage Matinee to a small but good audience at Mrs. Jones' house.

entries.fullText:
At Chicago - Mrs Young
Called at Aunt
A. E. Dickinsons -
Mr & Mrs Jones
took me Methodist
Missionary - "Women's"
annual meeting
heard Miss
of and
Mrs H. give
their annual reports -
- then they took me
to Depot for Milwaukee
- reached there early
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the annual meeting of the Methodist Missionary Women in Chicago and then traveled to Milwaukee with Mr. and Mrs. Jones.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Milwaukee at 6
A.M. found no train until
2 P.M. - the rain poured -
so did not call on dear
Lilie Beckham, Madam
Anneke nor Mary Stout
Roddis nor sister Annie &
sister Eunice - Tried
to take a sleep - but no
avail - arrived Ripon
at 8.15 - took cup of tea
& went direct to Hall -
stopped at Mrs Harris -
Streets perfect glare of ice
still a pretty fair audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Milwaukee and then Ripon, where she tried to rest but couldn't. She visited Mrs. Harris and spoke to a fair audience.

entries.fullText:
Up early & took
train for Jefferson -
Had fine
audience -the
Good Templars
got it up -
Did not go
to bed - took train
about 12 midnight for
Chicago - several
ladies & gentlemen
Stopped at Hotel till
train time - the Gentleman
who introduced
me was over seas - wife
[?] earnest W. S. woman
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a fine audience in Jefferson, organized by the Good Templars. She then took a train to Chicago and stayed at a hotel until her next train, meeting a woman who was an earnest W. S.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Chicago
7 A. M. walked
to Cousin P Laphams
and took breakfast
Then to see Mrs [?ou??]
& Judge Waite & then
to Aunt A E Dickinsons
& thence to Hannah
Dickinson Boyles
& staid all night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and visited several relatives and acquaintances before staying overnight at Hannah Dickinson Boyles' place.

entries.fullText:
Left Cousin
H Dick. Boyle's at
8 A.M. - 189 Sangamon
St. - had
Pallace Car State
room with Mrs
Adams Hinsdale
niece of Mr. Gifford
(Singer) Rochester
Found Mrs [M.?] B.
[?] - 323 Howard
St. Detroit - about
7.30 & stopped over night
Mrs C. F. Stebbins then -
Mrs Gardner had voted
a few days before -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Hannah Dickinson Boyles' place and traveled to Detroit, where she stayed overnight at Mrs [M.?] B.'s place. She also mentions Mrs Gardner, who had voted a few days before.

entries.fullText:
Ms. J.R. Whiting
stopped with Mrs.
Namey Higley -
Widow - pays large tax -
Mrs Wm. B. Baron
Had splendid meeting
rode from Huron
to St. Clair in
stage 12 miles -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a splendid meeting in St. Clair, Michigan with Ms. J.R. Whiting, Mrs. Namey Higley, and Mrs. Wm. B. Baron after riding 12 miles from Huron.

entries.fullText:
Took steamer
down St. Clair
Lake & River - very
beautiful -
& evening train to
Ann Arbor - had
pleasant visit at
the Halls -
Called at George
Fords - Maurice
looked just as
of yore - Mr. Ford
very aged and infirm
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a steamer down St. Clair Lake and River before taking an evening train to Ann Arbor. She had a pleasant visit at the Halls and called on George Fords where Maurice looked just as of yore, but Mr. Ford was very aged and infirm.

entries.fullText: Israel P. Halls
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on April 16, 1871 about meeting Israel P. Halls in Ann Arbor.

entries.fullText:
Had very good
meeting & pleasant
house at
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on April 17, 1871 about a good meeting with Frank H. Cobb in Hudson Mich.

entries.fullText: Ms P. H. M. Stickney and her husband Frank G. Stickney met me at the depot and took me to their home where I dined and rested until time to go to the hall. Splendid audience, note $50. 20 ct. admission. I spoke first - the strongest woman - Ms. Chesney next - Ms J. O. Wilcox last. Judge Harris best man.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a hall in Painesville Ohio to a splendid audience, noting the admission and the people who spoke before and after her.

entries.fullText: Took train to Dunkirk - where I slept at Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Dunkirk and sleeps at a hotel.

entries.fullText:
Took Erie Train
at 7:20, stopped
at Mrs -
had nice meeting -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train to Cuba, NY and had a nice meeting with O.S. Freeland.

entries.fullText:
Took private carriage
- because stage would
be so late - arrived
at R. found no preparations
for lecture -
trouble - agent had
written Underwood instead
of Woodworth -
so stopped over
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a private carriage to Rushford, NY and encountered trouble with the agent who had written the wrong name, so she stopped over in Olean All. Co. N.Y.

entries.dateText:
APRIL
22 Saturday
Rushford All. Co. N.Y.
entries.fullText:
Had fine audience
at 25 cts, hence no cash
visited Cheese
Factory
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a successful speaking engagement in Rushford All. Co. N.Y. and visited a Cheese Factory.

entries.dateText:
APRIL
23 Sunday
Took Carriage
back to Cuba &
took 4 P.M. Sunday
train for
Corning
entries.fullText:
Took Carriage
back to Cuba &
took 4 P.M. Sunday
train for
Corning
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Cuba to Corning by carriage and train on a Sunday.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Helen M. Brown
Found dear
Mrs Sleeper at
the Depot - had
fine audience
& good visit.
Mr Sleeper
very feeble - did
not go out -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Sleeper in Mt Morris, NY and has a good visit with her and Mrs. Helen M. Brown. Mr. Sleeper is too feeble to go out.

entries.fullText:
Took train into
Rochester - when
arrived about noon
went directly to
No. 7 Madison street -
Found all well &
as glad to see me
as I them & home -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Rochester and visits No. 7 Madison street where everyone is glad to see her.

entries.fullText:
Got black Alpacha
for traveling dress -
also black lace
& guipure for
trimmings too
steel Gray Silk presented
me my 50th
birthday 1870 - Feb 15 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about purchasing materials for a traveling dress and receiving a steel Gray Silk as a birthday present.

entries.fullText:
ordeal of
trying on dresses
& getting mended
up - washed up -
cleaned up &
fixed up generally
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about trying on dresses and getting cleaned up.

entries.fullText:
Labor Reform working men
New York.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Labor Reform working men in New York.

entries.fullText:
working men's meeting N.Y.
At Mrs Martins
Mrs Hooker
came to tea,
spent evening -
we wrote resolutions
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a working men's meeting in N.Y. at Mrs Martins, has tea with Mrs Hooker, and writes resolutions.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Hooker &
self went into
New York, she
to the Coleman
House & I to
Mrs Murrays
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs Hooker went to New York, with Mrs Hooker going to the Coleman House and Susan going to Mrs Murrays.

entries.fullText:
New York
Wendell Phillips Yeates
at Steinway Hall. A.M.
Reform League & evening at
Union League Hall.
standard subscriptions
pestered persons A.M.P.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended events in New York, including a speech by Wendell Phillips Yeates at Steinway Hall and an evening event at Union League Hall, and dealt with standard subscriptions and pestered persons in the morning.

entries.fullText:
American W.S. meeting
Steinway Hall
Passed resolutions
saying they were
not Free Loners
why not on saying
their men not
thieves & murders
staffed with Mrs
Murray.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends an American W.S. meeting at Steinway Hall where resolutions were passed and Mrs. Murray was present.

entries.fullText:
National W.S. meeting
Apollo Hall New York
Good audience
Mrs Hooker, Mrs
Davis, Mrs Stanton
The great trouble
allowing Mrs Wood
Hall on our
Platform
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a National W.S. meeting at Apollo Hall in New York where Mrs. Hooker, Mrs. Davis, Mrs. Stanton, and Mrs. Wood Hall were present.

entries.fullText:
Spent Sunday
with Mrs Stanton
& she decided
to go to California
with me.
Hattie actually
cried half the day
that her mother
would go, too mean
she said
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton and the author decided to go to California together, causing Hattie to cry.

entries.fullText:
[Took 8 A. M. train
for Bridgeport
stopped with Rev
Olympia Brown
Mrs Hooker not
here.]
entries.summaryText: The author took a train to Bridgeport and stayed with Rev Olympia Brown, but Mrs Hooker was not there.

entries.fullText:
[Went to Hartford
with Mrs Hooker again
& Olympia Brown
with us.]
Bridgeport - CT -
took 8 A.M. train -
Mrs Hooker & Mrs
Middlebrook -
Stopped with
Rev Olympia Brown
entries.summaryText: Went to Hartford with Mrs Hooker and Olympia Brown.

entries.fullText:
at Mrs. Hooker's
Mrs. Griffin's with
us - Olympia
Brown went up
with us - [?]
train -
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Hooker and Mrs. Griffin in Hartford with Olympia Brown.

entries.fullText:
Left Hartford
this A.M. drank
tea with old
friend Lydia
Mott & then
night train to
Rochester
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Hartford and had tea with her old friend Lydia Mott before taking a night train to Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Rochester
at 9.40 and went
direct to Dentist
Requa & had
front root extracted
for 20 years I had
worn pivot tooth.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and went directly to the dentist to have a front root extracted, which she had worn a pivot tooth for 20 years.

entries.fullText:
[Took 8 A.M.
train for
Bridgeport CT.,
stopped with
brave Rev.
Olympia Brown.]
Rochester
at home.
entries.summaryText: Took a train to Bridgeport CT and stayed with Rev. Olympia Brown.

entries.fullText:
Rochester
[went to Hartford
with Mrs Hooker
Olympia with
us, had
pleasant visit
also J. P. Griffin
of Washington]
entries.summaryText: Visited Hartford with Mrs Hooker and Olympia, had a pleasant visit with J. P. Griffin of Washington.

entries.fullText:
MAY
24 Wednesday
[Hartford CT
at Mrs. Hookers]
Rochester
entries.summaryText: Entry written on May 24th, 1871 in Hartford CT at Mrs. Hookers's place and mentions Rochester.

entries.cityOrState:
Left Hartford
this A.M.,
Luncheon with
Lydia Mott
& took night
train into
Rochester
entries.fullText:
MAY
25 Thursday
[Left Hartford
this A.M.,
Luncheon with
Lydia Mott
& took night
train into
Rochester]
Rochester
entries.summaryText: Entry written on May 25th, 1871 mentioning leaving Hartford, having lunch with Lydia Mott and taking a night train to Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Rochester, 9.40,
went direct to
Dr Requa's Dentist,
he formed front
tooth root split, so
the pivot was loose,
after deliberation &
his decision that I
could not get on
with it, he took out
the root, which had
held a pivot tooth for
24 years, & I
went home toothless
with prospect of a
rubber plate in my
mouth henceforth &
dreadful does it seem.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to the dentist and has a tooth removed, leaving her toothless and with the prospect of a rubber plate.

entries.fullText: Rochester
entries.summaryText: No significant events mentioned.

entries.fullText:
[?] - brought
her little Freddy
home for fear of
catching scarlet
fever - &
entries.summaryText: Hattie Baker brought her son home for fear of catching scarlet fever.

entries.fullText:
Spent A.M. at
Dr Requa's - getting
teeth fitted - Oh
for the old fraction
of a root back
again -
great anxiety
lest little Harry
shall take scarlet
fever
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the dentist and was anxious about her nephew getting scarlet fever.

entries.fullText:
Miss Vaughan
got Grendine basque
done - tolerably fair
- [Grover?] the
shoes - very good
- But the teeth
alas - alas - I
fear I can never
get them right -
at evening [?] & Mary
Hallowell called -
Unitarian minister
Mr Mann called before
I returned -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Miss Vaughan getting a Grendine basque done, shoes being very good, and her struggles with getting her teeth right. She also mentions visits from Mary Hallowell and Unitarian minister Mr. Mann.

entries.fullText:
Couldn't get off on
10 A.M. train -
went to Dentists
he fitted a third
plate - but I feel
no surety any of
them will be a
success -
Left on 10 night
train - arrived
at Erie Pa - at
3 A.M. & took bed
till 8 Thursday A.M.
Aaron & niece Maggie
went to Depot with me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her struggles with getting a dental plate fitted and her uncertainty about its success. She also mentions traveling to Erie, Pennsylvania with Aaron and niece Maggie.

entries.fullText:
Left Erie at 10.30
arrive Pittsburgh
4- P.M. - - took
supper & bed until
10 Oclock - Then
train to Mouth of
Mahoning - 2.30
A.M. - bed until
5 - then breakfast,
carriage at 6 A.M.
Friday -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Erie and arrived in Pittsburgh, then traveled to Mouth of Mahoning and stayed overnight before continuing her journey.

entries.fullText:
Brookville - Pa -
G.R. Barrett, &
Mr Marlin -,
Small Pox panic
made audience smaller
as well as awful heat -
Travelled
with Henry Young of
Geneseo - Ill - over
the mountains 33 miles
Dreadfully tired -
dined Millville -
Wind at backs -
dust terrific -
arrived at 4 P.M.
went straight to bed -
awful hot - pretty
fair audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Brookville, Pennsylvania with G.R. Barrett, Mr. Marlin, and Henry Young. The audience was smaller due to a smallpox panic and the heat was awful. She arrived in Millville after traveling 33 miles over the mountains and was dreadfully tired. She had a fair audience despite the heat and dust.

entries.fullText:
Left Brookville
at 9 A.M. - not so
warm as yesterday,
wind in our faces -
same Geneseo, Ill
Henry [Young?] on board
. Dined at Milleville -
16 miles - arrived at
mouth of Mahoning at
6 - took tea - & cars
at 7.20 to Pittsburgh
- arrived 11 - sat up until
1 - & then learned no
train to Xenia till
Sunday 11 A. M. So
went to bed, tired
& disgusted that nobody
should know the fact -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Brookville to Pittsburgh with Henry Young and experiences frustration when she learns there is no train to Xenia.

entries.fullText:
Left Pittsburgh
at 11 A M. - our
Pan Handle route for
Xenia O. arrived
at 9 P.M. Slept
at Hotel - hard
prospects - A tremendous
shower
about 3 P.M. -
much needed - every
thing suffering -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony continues her journey from Pittsburgh to Xenia and notes the much-needed rain in the area.

entries.fullText:
G.F. Moody -
Mrs. P. Rol[?] O.
Mr. Moody called
and took me to
Mrs Starretts sisters
Fanny's - Mrs
Matt. Allison
where I had good [?]
Mrs. A insisted
I should wear the steel
gray silk A. E. D.
gave me Birth day - &
it did look very nice -
This was the christening
entries.summaryText: Attended a christening at Mrs. Starretts sisters and wore a steel gray silk dress given to her by A. E. D. for her birthday.

entries.fullText:
Left Xenia at 11
A.M. arrived at
Richmond 2 P.M. and
stopped at Dr. Mary
F. Thomas' until 10
evening - found her
clear on Woodhull
work & the Ind. society
going to withdraw
from the American
Society
entries.summaryText: Traveled to Painesville and stayed with Dr. Mary F. Thomas who was clear on Woodhull work and the Ind. society going to withdraw from the American Society.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Chicago 8
A.M. - breakfasted
with Aunt A. E. Dickinson
and found all well -
Called on Judge Waite
& he took me to their
new City suffrage rooms
very nice - at 5 went
to Mrs Jones - Mr
& Mrs. Brooks called
in evening - Mr B will
get me pass to
Omaha
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Chicago, visits suffrage rooms and meets with acquaintances.

entries.fullText:
Chicago — at Mrs. Jones
Drove round to
meet Mrs. Stanton at
Mich. Southern R.R. at
8.22 A.M. - She
got letter off to The
Revolution - and at
3 P.M. we all went
suffrage rooms 145
Madison St - to reception
- a good many there,
all splendid - went
to Mr Bowen’s to
tea — had to leave &
take 10 o’clock R.R. train -
found trunks not there
left word to double check
them to Des Moines -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a suffrage reception and has tea with Mr. Bowen in Chicago before leaving for Des Moines.

entries.fullText: Mrs Maria Gray Pittman arrived at 4 P.M. Mrs Pitman & Mrs Calanan met us - a thunder storm came just at lecture hour so Stanton's audience was was small - in Court House after meeting Mrs S. went home with Mrs Savory - Saturday A.M. the trunks came all right -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Maria Gray Pittman arrived at 4 P.M. and we had a small audience due to a thunderstorm during Stanton's lecture.

entries.fullText: Mr Caldanan took us both to his house to dinner, and then back to 3 Oclock talk with women alone - very interesting meeting - no letters from home - feel very anxious to learn fate of Hattie Bakers boy - darling little Henry - also of our mother whom I left unusually feeble - Reception at Mrs Pittmans this evening
entries.summaryText: We had an interesting meeting with women and I am anxious to learn about Hattie Bakers' boy and our mother's health. Reception at Mrs. Pittman's in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Savory sent
carriage for me & I
spent day at her beautiful
home - Lizzie
Boynton Harbert &
husband - Henry Oldman
Pres. of State W.S. society
there - cares, as do all
the men champions - mostly
more for his own and
Repub. party success than
for woman suffrage.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Savory's home in Des Moisnes Iowa with Lizzie Boynton Harbert, Henry Oldman, and other members of the State W.S. society.

entries.fullText:
Spent day at
Mrs Pitmans - writing
letters - Did receive
a letter - but did two
rolls of [?] -
Went to Mrs P's
Dentist to see if my
teeth could be fixed
but of no avail -
Took [?] R.R.
at 4 P.M. - arrived at
Bluffs at 11 - D.C. Bloomer
at Depot - took to his house
- undertook to sleep with
Stanton - but no use -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Pitmans' writing letters and attempting to fix her teeth before taking the train to Bluffs where she stays with D.C. Bloomer and Stanton.

entries.fullText:
I left C. Bluffs at 5.50 A.M. &
arrived Sioux City 11.55
Mr Wilkins & Mr
Collins Ed. Daily Times
took me round town
to see & be seen I suppose -
& then to Northwestern
Hotel - Barnes, Edson proprietors -
ate dinner &
went to bed & slept till
tea time -
no letters or papers
here -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Sioux City and is taken around town by Mr. Wilkins and Mr. Collins before retiring to the Northwestern Hotel.

entries.fullText:
At 9 A.M. Wilkins
& wife & Dr.
wife called & took me
riding over the bluffs -
visited the grave of the
Big Sioux Indian chief &
crossed the Big Sioux
into Dacotah Territory
and there lunched on
the banks of the river -
returned at 12 - wrote
twelve letters - took nap
& to Academy of Music -
Good audience - Mr
& Mrs Angley of Dacotah City
over - engaged both Stanton
& Anthony to W.S.W. for next winter
at $7
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes on a ride with W.L. Wilkins and visits the grave of a Big Sioux Indian chief before writing letters and attending the Academy of Music.

entries.fullText: Rev. W. P. Morrison left Sioux City, 6.30 A.M. arrived F.D. 12.10 noon Mr Barnes of Sioux City just opened Iowa House at F.D. Splendid audience But oh the Bed buggy room
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Rev. W. P. Morrison leaving Sioux City and arriving at F.D. with Mr Barnes of Sioux City who just opened Iowa House at F.D. She also mentions a splendid audience and a bad bed buggy room.

entries.fullText: Josiah Armstrong $30 & all nett over-- Splendid audience stopped at McLean's Hotel. nice little Ct. woman for wife. Ms Stanton at Lincoln Neb. Constitutional Convention in session
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Josiah Armstrong's earnings and a splendid audience in Cherokee Iowa. She also mentions staying at McLean's Hotel and a nice little Ct. woman for wife. Ms Stanton is mentioned to be at the Lincoln Neb. Constitutional Convention in session.

entries.fullText:
D. M. Harris
Ed. Harrisonian
Small audience
but some good
done perhaps
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a small audience and some good done in Missouri Valley Junction.

entries.fullText:
Went down
to Mrs Bloomers
found Mrs L.
Stone - dreadfully
hot day
Went over
to Wyoming Hotel
Omaha in P. M.
met Mrs Train's
uncle Geo Frost
who took us in
his carriage
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs Bloomers and the Wyoming Hotel in Omaha and meets Mrs Train's uncle Geo Frost who takes them in his carriage.

entries.fullText:
Omaha. Neb.
Wyoming Hotel [?]
A.S. Paddock Prop.
Territorial-secretary
& acting governor.
Ms. S spoke in the
Academy of Music
same that echoed to G.F
Train Stanton & [?]
Nov. 19th 1867.
Gen. P. Bemis. [?]
private sec'y & his wife
Julia Brown. [?]
[got ? over M.P.R.R.]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Omaha, Nebraska and stays at the Wyoming Hotel. She speaks at the Academy of Music and mentions A.S. Paddock, G.F Train Stanton, Gen. P. Bemis, and Julia Brown.

entries.fullText:
Mr Siskels Telegraph
give passes to S.B. & [?]
over Union Pacific
received it just
at last moment
of taking train at
11.30
Julia &
Bemis accompanied
us to
the Depot
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives passes from Mr. Siskels to travel over Union Pacific and is accompanied by Julia and Bemis to the Depot.

entries.fullText: Mrs. M. H. Arnold Amelia B. Post - bath Mrs. Stanton had small audience - arrived about noon Mrs Stanton slept at Mrs Ports, I at Mrs Arnolds
entries.summaryText: Mrs. M. H. Arnold, Amelia B. Post, and Mrs. Stanton had a small audience in Cheyenne. They arrived around noon and stayed at different places.

entries.fullText: Went down to Denver. Mrs McCook met us at Depot & took us to her new & lovely house - the Gov. was absent Church Howe took us riding to Fort David Russell got passes to Denver
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Denver with Mrs. McCook and stayed at her new house. They went riding to Fort David Russell and got passes to Denver.

entries.fullText:
[Greeley - Col -]
[Ralph Meeker]
Denver - Col
Mrs Mary M. Cook
I spoke this
evening in Opera
House, splendid
audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke in Opera House in Denver, Colorado to a splendid audience including Ralph Meeker and Mrs Mary M. Cook.

entries.fullText:
Greeley - Col
Ralph Meeker
Splendid audience -
Mrs S. spoke
to the Denver
women alone
this P. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a splendid audience in Greeley, Colorado including Ralph Meeker. Mrs S. spoke to the Denver women alone this afternoon.

entries.fullText:
Arrived from
Greeley at noon
Went to Mrs
Potts - had a
packed house
for audience.
Mrs S. spoke at
Denver this evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Cheyenne from Greeley and spoke at Mrs. Potts' house to a packed audience. Mrs. S. spoke in Denver that evening.

entries.fullText:
Mr J. H. Hugford
Very small
audience - Mrs.
Lake's Circus
here -
Mrs S.
spoke at Greeley
this evening
Got check for
$200. on {?} bank
to send to R. J. Johnston
for printing Seneca Falls report
of 1848 with Stanton's first speech
She gave $100. of this - the very first
she ever contributed to fund - any of
her own speeches even -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a very small audience in Laramie, Wy. Mrs. S. spoke in Greeley that evening. She received a check for $200 to send to R. J. Johnston for printing Seneca Falls report of 1848 with Stanton's first speech. She contributed $100 of her own money to the fund, the very first time she had ever done so.

entries.fullText:
Took train at
12 noon - Mrs
Stanton on board
scenery beyond
description -
100 women at Depot
Mrs S. addressed
them on platform
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Stanton took a train with 100 women and enjoyed the scenery.

entries.fullText:
Salt Lake arrived
about 7 P. M. Stopped
Townsend House
Mr Godbe met
us at Depot
Brigham Young
gone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Salt Lake and stayed at Townsend House. Mr. Godbe met them at the depot and Brigham Young was gone.

entries.fullText:
W.S. Godbe his
uncle Daniel Grant
arranged for us -
Mrs Stanton spoke
Mayor Wells introduced -
4 or 500
present -
Mr Grant took
us to call at the
Mayors house.
[?] his wife - [?]
of fine
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Salt Lake City, Utah and attends a meeting with W.S. Godbe, Daniel Grant, Mrs. Stanton, and Mayor Wells. They visit the Mayor's house.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Stanton
had large meeting
of women alone in
[Big] Old Tabernacle
very interesting -
I spoke in evening
to a very small house.
Bishop Pratt introduced
me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting with Mrs. Stanton and Bishop Pratt in Salt Lake.

entries.fullText:
Received calls all
day -
Mrs Pitts Stevens
arrived Sunday
A. M. from
San Fancisco
entries.summaryText: Received calls all day - Mrs Pitts Stevens arrived Sunday A. M. from San Fancisco

entries.fullText:
Ms S. staid home
to write - I went to
Dedication of the
Liberal Institute.
It was a most enthusiastic
meeting - I
asked the men if
they had thought whether
the women by their
side were rejoicing
in equal freedom
from all intervention
of man between them
and their God!! - went
to Big Tabernacle in
P.M., Geo. T. [C?]
entries.summaryText: Ms S. staid home to write - I went to Dedication of the Liberal Institute. It was a most enthusiastic meeting - I asked the men if they had thought whether the women by their side were rejoicing in equal freedom from all intervention of man between them and their God!! - went to Big Tabernacle in P.M., Geo. T. [C?]

entries.fullText:
Sunday - last night
Mrs Stanton gave
her written lecture
The True Republic to a
packed house in
new Liberal Institute
The Camp Dr.
took us out to the
camp to tea Sunday
P.M. -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton gave her written lecture The True Republic to a packed house in new Liberal Institute and The Camp Dr. took us out to the camp to tea Sunday P.M.

entries.fullText:
Stanton & Anthony
went Big Tabernacle
Saw it filled - Mrs
S. staid there - I went
over to new Liberal
Institute - those come
outers from Mormontown
were rejoicing in Womens
new freedom. - Since
the days of Patrick Henry
I do not believe the
Declaration has been
pronounced with
such emotion - dined
with Mrs.Mary Godbe -
entries.summaryText: Stanton & Anthony went Big Tabernacle and saw it filled. Those come outers from Mormontown were rejoicing in Womens new freedom. Since the days of Patrick Henry I do not believe the Declaration has been pronounced with such emotion. Dined with Mrs.Mary Godbe.

entries.fullText:
Meeting of the
Women's improvement
Society in new
Liberal Institute
200 present. Splendid
time. Stanton [dined] took tea
with Mrs. Mary Godbe
& with Mrs. Annie Godbe
Gov. Stanford
telegraphed us
passes to San
Francisco.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting of the Women's Improvement Society at the new Liberal Institute with 200 people present. She has tea with Mrs. Mary Godbe and Mrs. Annie Godbe and receives passes to San Francisco from Gov. Stanford.

entries.fullText:
Took cars for
Corinne - [Super -]
No passes over
Bingham R.R.
for anybody.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Corinne but finds out that there are no passes over Bingham R.R. for anyone.

entries.fullText:
I had little
meeting in P.M.
and we took the
train at 7 P.M.
Mrs. Hetty
Painter is the
working best woman
here - is a Doctor.
Wrote letter on
Salt Lake back to
The Revolution
from Coviner
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a meeting and train ride in Corinne, Utah. She mentions Mrs. Hetty Painter, a doctor who is the best working woman in the area. She also wrote a letter to The Revolution from Coviner.

entries.fullText:
All the sage
brush desert -
Mrs Peter McIntosh
Rock Hampton
Queensland
Australia
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the sagebrush desert and mentions Mrs. Peter McIntosh from Rock Hampton, Queensland, Australia.

entries.fullText:
On C.P.R.R. Porter
George called
us at 4 a.m.
to see Donner Lake
and the Sierra
Nevada Mountains.
- sublime. - beyond
anything ever seen.
Arrived San Fran
at 6 - Col. John A.
Collins met us at
Oakland - went to
Grand Hotel.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and George visit Donner Lake and the Sierra Nevada Mountains before arriving in San Francisco and meeting with Col. John A. Collins at the Grand Hotel.

entries.fullText:
San Fran. - took
a look at all the
Hotels. but decided
to stick to Grand -
perfect run of
calls all day.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day in San Francisco looking at hotels but ultimately decides to stay at the Grand Hotel and has a productive day of calls.

entries.fullText: Mrs. E. C. S. spoke first time in Platts Hall - splendid audience - 1200 - Womens Suffrage speech Everybody delighted
entries.summaryText: Mrs. E. C. S. gave a Women's Suffrage speech for the first time in Platts Hall to a splendid audience of 1200 people who were delighted.

entries.fullText: S. B. A. spoke Platts Hall - Power of the Ballot - a splendid audience - & great speech - Hisses at allusion to Laura Fair - but I silenced them & then turned them to cheers - 1200 -
entries.summaryText: S. B. A. gave a great speech on the Power of the Ballot at Platts Hall to a splendid audience of 1200 people. There were hisses at an allusion to Laura Fair, but S. B. A. silenced them and turned them to cheers.

entries.fullText:
& Maternity to
women - only - at
Platts Hall- 400
present - splendid
meeting -
Every paper came
out terrifically against
me & my speech last
night - never before
got such a raking
Mrs. S. went to see
Tuwra Fair in A.M.
forwarded her a beautiful
sweet woman
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a meeting at Platts Hall in San Francisco, where she faces criticism from the press. Mrs. S. goes to see Tuwra Fair in the morning.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. Platts Hall. -
Woman Suffrage & True
Love. Large
house again -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a meeting at Platts Hall in San Francisco about woman suffrage and true love.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. went home
with Mrs Schenck
I went with Col.
J.A. Collins & wife
to San Rafael to
speak - stopped
at Mrs Du Bois
Col & wife
at Irwins
had small meeting
and the shadow
of the newspapers luming
over me every minute
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to San Rafael with Col. J.A. Collins and his wife to speak and had a small meeting.

entries.fullText:
Mr Collins took
A.M. boat home
Mr & Mrs Irwin
took Mrs Collins &
me a ride round
the mountains - San
Rafel is in the
most beautifully
sheltered valley -
took 2 P.M. boat
to San. Fran. and
went up to Mrs
Schencks - dense
fog - almost rain -
& really cold -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went on a ride around the mountains with Mr. and Mrs. Irwin and took a boat to San Fran. to visit Mrs. Schencks.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. S. & Pitts Stevens
went to San Jose - I to
Grand Hotel -
Mrs Hurburt called
for me to go to see
Mrs Higby - who was
knocked down by a
ruffian the night before
- Mrs Hurburt is the
sister of Hydenfelt -
Judge of Supreme Court
for five - - Mr. H.
lives with woman who
officiates at his table
& the mother of five
children - but not his
legal wife - Mrs Higby
very badly hurt - no clue
at the person -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits San Jose and the Grand Hotel. She visits Mrs. Higby who was knocked down by a ruffian the night before. She also meets Mrs. Hurburt, the sister of Hydenfelt, Judge of Supreme Court for five. She learns that Mr. H. lives with a woman who officiates at his table and is the mother of five children but not his legal wife. Mrs. Higby is badly hurt and there is no clue about the person who did it.

entries.fullText:
Gov. Stanford gave
us [threw?] monthly [hall?] -
San Fran - Grand Hotel
Mr W. S Gadbe of
Salt Lake here - &
his presence made
