me feel quite at
home - or somewhat
relieved me of
loneliness from absence
of Mrs Stanton -
Have been
experimenting with
Dentist Knowles
since my first arrival -
but he fails
to better Dr. Requa's
first job - Gula clasp[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends Gov. Stanford's monthly hall in San Fran at the Grand Hotel. Mr. W. S Gadbe of Salt Lake is also present. She feels relieved of loneliness from the absence of Mrs. Stanton. She has been experimenting with Dentist Knowles but he fails to better Dr. Requa's first job - Gula clasp.

entries.fullText:
Had sent out
tickets to ladies
to Mrs. Stanton's Marriage
& Divorce tomorrow.
This A.M.'s papers
announced its postponement -
I went
in search of Collins
& found it done by
his order from Stanton -
closed bill & went
home with Collins -
had nice dinner,
had letter from Sister
Mary - found Rev. J.R.
McLean was probably at [Lick?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had sent out tickets to ladies for Mrs. Stanton's Marriage & Divorce tomorrow, but it was postponed. She had a nice dinner and received a letter from Sister Mary. She found out that Rev. J.R. McLean was probably at [Lick?]

entries.fullText:
House so went
down to see them -
but decided not
to wait for them to
go Yosemite Valley -
Took 4 P.M. train
for Stockton to join
Mrs Stanton - found
Miss M. A. Thomson,
Mrs Cook of Phila -
there waiting to see me
- they were just returned
from Yosemite - but
the clouds are so
heavy over me - I
could not greet them.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Stockton to join Mrs. Stanton. She found Miss M. A. Thomson and Mrs Cook of Phila waiting to see her, but the clouds were heavy over her and she could not greet them.

entries.fullText:
as I would -I never
was so dreadfully cut
down by any expression
of me or my powers -
Mrs S. bought two
brown straw hats
trimmed with tissue
veil material. Very
pretty - but too nice
to wear Yosemite. -
So stored them in box
for return -
Saw Mrs Curtis
of Detroit who fell
from her horse at
Yosemite. Miss
Mercy & D. Inge joined
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about feeling cut down and mentions buying hats and seeing Mrs. Curtis who fell from her horse at Yosemite.

entries.fullText:
Stanton & Anthony
with private carriage
Harrison [Dunaway?]
arrived - & we started
at 7 A.M. Cars to
Milton - where carriage
was waiting. Dined
at Gibsons - horrid
food - meeting at
Murphys - little church
- Sperry Hotel
Mrs Proper formerly
of Syracuse House
keeper - good [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about traveling with Stanton and Anthony, dining at Gibsons, and attending a meeting at Murphys.

entries.fullText:
Drove over to
Big Trees. Calamens
group. Up the
little Miners creek,
dashing down the
ravines. The
road rough and
long fearful
precipices. Arrived
at 12 noon. Dined
& made the circuit
of the Saquoyas, the
giants of the forest.
They put to flight all
the old six days story
& the 6,000 years.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony drove to Big Trees, Calamens group, and made the circuit of the Saquoyas, the giants of the forest.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. S had conversations
in Perry's
Hotel Parlor last eve -
- I was up & took
another circuit of
the monster trees before
breakfast. - then
dashed down the
mountains again
to Murphy's thence
down the mountain
& crossed the Stanislaus
river Ferry - then up
a long zig-zag mountain
road through Gold
Spring, Columbia, Springfield,
Columbia. Shaws
flats - to Sonora - I
spoke Court House - fair
audience - Mrs S. wrote
Rev - - 30 miles
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took another circuit of the monster trees before breakfast and then drove to Sonora, speaking at the Court House to a fair audience.

entries.fullText:
Left Seneca about
8 A.M. drove
over mountain to
Jacksonville 19 miles
stopped at Reiths
fruit garden had
peaches, apples, plums &
grapes with crackers &
milk- Then to the
ferry of the [?]
Liner - old man &
not a woman in house
he said - from this
is was winding up, up
the longest steepest mountain
road - scenery magnificent
to Kirklands
& [?] to [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Seneca and drove over a mountain to Jacksonville, stopping at Reiths fruit garden and taking a ferry. She encountered an old man and enjoyed the magnificent scenery.

entries.fullText:
[?] to Cranes
[?] during
Heodgkins [?]
Mrs. [?] gave
us nice [?] &
coffee in AM
[?]did broiled
chicken.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Cranes and Heodgkins, where she was given nice food and coffee by Mrs. [?].

entries.fullText:
Rode from Crane
Flats to brow of
the Hill. I was
on horse Belle &
Mrs Stanton on Morro
but Mrs. S quickly
declared it impossible
for her to ride - &
started & walked -
I rode on down, down
arrived at 2 P.M.
exhausted - sent back
guide with wine &
lunch to Mrs. S. She came
at 6 perfectly [?] up
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Stanton rode horses from Crane Flats to the brow of the Hill, but Mrs. Stanton found it impossible to continue riding and walked instead. Susan arrived exhausted at 2 P.M. and sent back a guide with wine and lunch to Mrs. Stanton, who arrived at 6 P.M. perfectly fine.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. S. took breakfast
in bed -
went with McLean
Party 5 miles to
Nevada Falls - the
Snow House & back
to Vernal - & thence
to Mirror Lake
on Lady Franklin
rock we met Mrs
Stanton - to our
great surprise.
My guides name
Stephen McCunnington
Millerton Fresno Co. Cal.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. S. went with McLean Party to Nevada Falls, Snow House, Vernal, and Mirror Lake. On Lady Franklin rock, they met Mrs. Stanton to their great surprise. Susan's guide's name was Stephen McCunnington from Millerton Fresno Co. Cal.

entries.fullText:
I rode to Artists
Point with Steven
M. Cunningham
for guide - 7 miles
& return 14. Mr
C. one of the earliest
visitors to the Valley -
most splendid
view. -, but
tired tired on
return. Lost the
cameo breast pin
cousin Eleanor
Caldwell gave me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony rode to Artists Point with Steven M. Cunningham as a guide and lost a cameo breast pin given to her by cousin Eleanor Caldwell.

entries.fullText:
John K. McLean
& self went to
Mirror Lake. - Saw
the sun rise - &
such a spectacle
eye can never
find elsewhere.
At 2 P.M. Mrs
S. in slumber bags -
& I on horseback with
S.M. Cunningham
for Guide - &
Geo. W. King of
Auburn - artist -
Martin of [Minnesota?]
found earrings &
drove to Cranes Flats -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Mirror Lake with John K. McLean and saw the sunrise. Later, she went horseback riding with S.M. Cunningham, Geo. W. King, and Martin to Cranes Flats where they found earrings.

entries.fullText:
Coulterville to
Knights Ferry -
dined at Mother
Stevens - scenery
flat & state open
the grandeur
of -

Stephen M. Cunningham
Millerton
Fresno Ct
Cal -
entries.summaryText: Travel from Coulterville to Knights Ferry, dined at Mother Stevens, and observed the scenery.

entries.fullText:
Cranes Flats to
Bower Cave -
a wonderful
freak from
natures upheavals.
Stopped several times
then rode to
Coultersville in
evening - Mrs
Steiner this
day surpassingly
grand -
entries.summaryText: Visited Bower Cave and Coultersville, and was impressed by the natural beauty.

entries.fullText:
Rode from
Knights Ferry
to Milton & got
train at 9.15 -
arrived Stockton
at 11 - saw my
friends - Find
the republican
campaign opened
it will interfere
with our meetings
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Knights Ferry to Milton and then to Stockton where she meets with friends and notes that the Republican campaign has opened and may interfere with their meetings.

entries.fullText:
Took train at 8 -
arrived S. Rosa at
12.30 - went to Mr
C. G. Aimes - very
small audience
but all seemed to
feel it a good speech
Rev Mr Brown of
Sacramento there
splendid man -
Mrs Stanton postponed
Stockton meeting, because
of Judge Bingham &
Senator Cole speaking -
which vexed Collins -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to S. Rosa and gives a speech to a small audience. She meets with Mr. C. G. Aimes and Rev Mr Brown. Mrs Stanton postpones a meeting in Stockton due to Judge Bingham and Senator Cole speaking, which vexes Collins.

entries.fullText:
Ira Allen
Mrs Ames & I called
at Mrs Halls and
Mrs Wallace & missed
the train - so
went to Santa Clara
& dined with Mrs
Watson - then back
& found Mrs McGee
& Mrs Knox -
entries.summaryText: Ira Allen, Mrs Ames, Mrs Halls, Mrs Wallace, Mrs Watson, Mrs McGee, and Mrs Knox were mentioned. They missed the train and went to Santa Clara instead.

entries.fullText:
Left Mrs C. G. Ames
on stage at 10 for
Santa Cruz - rode
on top - splendid
mountain scenery
and perfectly awful
hard ride - only a
few passengers -
splendid audience
tolerable speech - considering
35 miles
ride - arrival at
4 etc -- Mrs S. at
Sacramento to women
alone - Mr Collins would
not let her go back & fill
Stockton engagement to night
entries.summaryText: Mrs C. G. Ames was left in Santa Cruz. Mrs S. was in Sacramento alone and Mr Collins did not let her go back to fill the Stockton engagement tonight.

entries.fullText:
Spent two hours
with Mrs Georgianna
Bruce Kirby - [the]
Mrs Larkin with me
- Miss Cone of
Brooklyn visiting
her -
M R. C. Kirby -
Mrs Herring sister
of Mrs Van Valkenburg
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Mrs. Georgianna Bruce Kirby, Mrs. Larkin, Miss Cone of Brooklyn, M R. C. Kirby, and Mrs. Herring, in Santa Cruz.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Larkin drove
me over to Watsonville -
stopped Washington Hotel
Spoke Allens Hall - small
audience - Mr
Ira Allen a true
friend of woman suffrage
always a terrible
blunder to change
time or miss appointment -
Mr Allen said
hall would have been
packed Friday night -
Mrs Sarlein tired
out with her baby -
still staid to lecture &
was up & off with her
two horses by six O clock
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is driven by Mrs. Larkin to Watsonville, where she speaks at Allens Hall to a small audience. Mr. Ira Allen is a true friend of woman suffrage. Mrs. Sarlein stays to lecture despite being tired out with her baby and leaves with her two horses by six o'clock.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Larkin off at
6 A.M. - I took stage
at 9 - by mistake did
not get on the
mountain route
so missed the splendid
scenery - dreadfully
tired reached the
Grand Hotel - San
Francisco at 6 P.M.
Found no letter or
word from Stanton
or Collins - & too
late to find any body
at business places - so
dined & scribbled & went
to bed - good to be in
good clean quarters
with splendid things
to eat once more -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in San Francisco and is disappointed to find no letters from Stanton or Collins.

entries.fullText:
Grand Hotel - San Fran
Paid Knowles - $20
for gold plate - though
I believe some Dentist
can improve upon
them vastly -
Letter from R. J. J.
saying $200 check
dated June 26th on
Cheyenne bank not
received - yet was
mailed Salt Lake
also letter from sister
Mary saying two $50 P.O.
orders not received -
dated July 15th -
Col. G. & Mrs Stevens
called - no fixed meeting
for me -Took 4 boat for
Valdez & [Callastoga?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from R. J. J. and her sister Mary about missing payments. She also meets with Col. G. and Mrs. Stevens but no fixed meeting is set.

entries.fullText:
From Calastoga
to Guysers - Mr
Foss would not let
me ride on front
seat with him -
got half way - met
Mrs Stanton & J. R. McLean
coming out -
but I pushed on -
Wash Grainer my
Driver & he explained
the philosophy of fast
driving down those
mountains -
R. W. White teacher
no
entries.summaryText: Susan travels from Calastoga to Guysers, meets Mrs Stanton and J. R. McLean, and learns about the philosophy of fast driving down mountains from her driver Wash Grainer.

entries.fullText:
Geysers - Susan Bettis
Hotel
R. W. White & M L.
Clawson - N. Z. City
Teachers & their guests
made circuit of [???]
between 5 & 7 A, M, - 8
stage to Calastoga - was
honored with seat
with Mr Foss down
the mountain - & such
a sad domestic history
as he gave me -
found Mrs Stanton
at Calastoga Hotel =
she spoke at Vallejo &
I stopped at Dr. A.
Anderson's - Mother &
5 daughters - Scotch people
J.A. Collins there
entries.summaryText: Susan stays at the Geysers Susan Bettis Hotel and meets with R. W. White, M L. Clawson, Mr Foss, Mrs Stanton, and J.A. Collins. She also stops at Dr. A. Anderson's and meets a family of Scotch people.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. spoke
to the women
in P.M. - she
stopped with
Mrs Denio -
at 6 we returned
to San Francisco
Grand Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Mrs S. spoke to the women and stopped with Mrs Denio in San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. & self
Had quiet
day of rest -
No one calling
but Mr & Mrs
Stevens -
They told us of Mr John
A Collin's ursurpations of
the management of Mrs
Stefens Pioneer &
said so soon as she
could get him paid
off she should break
loose from his grip -
entries.summaryText: Mrs S. and the author had a quiet day of rest in an unknown location. They spoke with Mr & Mrs Stevens who told them about Mr John A Collin's usurpations of the management of Mrs Stefens Pioneer.

entries.fullText:
Mrs S. gave
Our young girls -
a good audience
though largely
complimentary -
Mrs Stevens got up
lecture & had all
receipts - netted
about $150. took
less than $250.
entries.summaryText: Mrs S. gave a lecture to a good audience in San Francisco. Mrs Stevens got up lecture and had all receipts, netted about $150.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Stanton spoke
at Oakland - [?]
called - It now
became evident that
a desperate effort
must be made to
fill the house Friday
night - so I
demanded 1000.
complimentary tickets.
there was a good
deal of hem & haw
but promise came -
& I mailed 600
to first class women
of the city -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton spoke at Oakland. Susan B. Anthony demanded 1000 complimentary tickets to fill the house Friday night. She mailed 600 to first class women of the city.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Schenck took
me in carriage too
schools & assylums
& I gave tickets
to teachers & officals
& made many
private calls on
best Ladies & gave
them some to give
their friends - &
tired out I was
when night came
Mrs S. spoke to
women in Oakland
this P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits schools and asylums in Oakland, gives tickets to teachers and officials, makes private calls on best ladies, and Mrs. Schenck speaks to women in Oakland.

entries.fullText:
Woodland -
Judge Sprague -
I tool Vallejo
Boat at 8. cold &
shivery - & at 12
arrived at Woodland -
into a real Turkish
Bath - so fiery hot -
- spoke to 100 people -
Mrs Stanton's audience -
- and of course a
disappointed one - & a
dreadfully hard one
to speak to - But the
Judge said the
argument was a good
one - no criticism on
our part of people
save that it wasnt
from the right person
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to 100 people in Woodland, including Mrs. Stanton's audience, and receives positive feedback from Judge Sprague despite disappointment from the audience.

entries.fullText: Mrs. S. gave Marriage & Divorce - packed house - of 1200 - over one half complimentary tickets - $329.= 658 tickets sold - the people seemed to accept every word. the reports added no adjectives but copies from published speech I carried them during Friday P. M. - could she - would she if she could do so much to put Editors right as to what I am, say or do? - I have not yet heard of or seen one word in refutation of the San Francisco Press outrageous treatment of my lecture - & she has written many letters public & private
entries.summaryText: Mrs. S. gave a lecture on Marriage & Divorce to a packed house of 1200 in San Francisco. Susan B. Anthony carried copies of reports from published speeches during Friday P.M. and expressed frustration with the San Francisco Press' treatment of her lecture.

entries.fullText: Left Grand Hotel at 8 - for Santa Cruz - Mrs Stevens joined us - arrived at 4 - Mrs S. spoke - the stage ride dreadfully dusty & hot - Small audience lack of right management in advertising -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left the Grand Hotel for Santa Cruz with Mrs. Stevens and arrived at 4. Mrs. S. spoke to a small audience and there was a lack of proper advertising management.

entries.fullText:
at Ellen A. Van Volkenbergs -
Mrs. S.
called at Mrs Blackburns
to see Mrs
Kirby - Mr R. C. Kuty
to me a ride to see
the farm & house
of Shiga W Farnberg
& told me much of
her - I spoke at 2
P.M. - took tea at
Mrs Blackburns -
Mrs S. spoke to a
large audience in
evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at 2 P.M. and takes tea at Mrs. Blackburns. Mrs. S. speaks to a large audience in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Santa Cruz -
Capt. Brown took
Mrs S. to Big Trees & to
top of mountain - I take
stage at 8 - we reached
San Francisco at 5.30
- Saw Mrs Collins -
- packed trunks -
and talked business
matters - We really
shall have very little
more than the $[1700.?]
currency - ($540. gold) - now
in Bank - unless Mrs S.
should make something this
week before leaving --
Tuesday A. M. after paying
off all bills - I had $70.
left in my hands -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Big Trees and the top of a mountain with Capt. Brown. She reaches San Francisco at 5.30 and talks business matters with Mrs. Collins. She has $70 left in her hands after paying off all bills.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Stanton - left for
Nevada City = Virginia
City, to start East on
Sunday 27th - I sat
for picture - & then
went to Oakland to
visit Mary Perkins
Randall & Martha P.
Perry - found them
happy to see me - am
myself glad to talk
over olden times &
get out of the reform
rut entirely for a time -
They seem to be
wholly oblivious to
our reform agitation
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talks about Mrs. Stanton leaving for Nevada City and visiting Mary Perkins Randall and Martha P. Perry in Oakland.

entries.fullText:
Mary & her
only son Jaynes
took me to the Mills
Institute - in Alameda
- a female boarding school -
- all very well - as well
perhaps as a girls school
can be - but it saddened
me to feel how aimless
were the 100 girls studying
there with might & main -
In P.M. Martha took
me to call on the Curtis
family - them I got
back into my world again
& the springs of thought &
conversation at once
loosed again - it is
marvelous what apart
worlds the two are -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Mills Institute in Alameda and feels saddened by the aimlessness of the girls studying there. Later, she visits the Curtis family and feels like she's back in her world again.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Selia Curtis
of Oakland & daughters
accompanied me on
to San Francisco -
Visited Ladies Wood
Engravers - Crane &
Curtis - & went to
Mrs Schencks &
spent night -
had a good visit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits San Francisco with Mrs Selia Curtis and her daughters, visits Ladies Wood Engravers and spends the night at Mrs Schencks' place.

entries.fullText:
Saw two whales
Mrs Schenck drove
me to G. Hotel at 8 A.M.
- then at 10.30 took
me to steam
ship Idaho - Capt
Floyd - for Portland
Oregon - I felt sad
& forlorn enough to be
thus left & ocean bound
alone - but was in for
it & bound to go through
- Ate lunch on
board Sat on deck
- packed & filed with boxes
& bags & barrels. Tried not
see, hear, nor smell the
heavings up below & all
around me - but ere
Six P.M. my time came
& old ocean received her
first installment from me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves San Francisco with Mrs Schenck and boards the steamship Idaho captained by Capt Floyd for Portland, Oregon. She feels sad and forlorn but is determined to go through with it. She eats lunch on board and tries not to get seasick, but eventually succumbs to it by 6 P.M.

entries.fullText:
1st A. M. on Idaho -
Dreadfully nauseated
all night - strong
gale & rough sea -
Tried to dress -
no use - back to my
berth - & then laid
all day - Everybody
on all sides heavng
groaning - babies &
children innumerable
vomiting & crying - mothers
scolding - & screeching
Horace - George - oh
dear dear - Stewardess
do come - the men
quite as noisy &
groaning as women -
all day long sick
as death midst these most
sickening sounds & smells
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes her experience on a ship to Idaho, where she was nauseated all night and all day amidst the sounds and smells of vomiting and crying babies and children.

entries.fullText:
2d Morn'g on ship board -
Tried to get up - but
no go - water gruel in
bed again - during
day thought staggered
& reeled to deck in
calico wrapper - men
on all the bags & boxes
sunning themselves -
looking as wretchedly
as I felt - back to
bed again - Capt
sent frizzled ham
& hard bread with [Cruptiments?]
- had frequently
before sent compliments &
enquiry for my getting on
Sea growing
heavier all the
time -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony continues to feel sick on the ship and is unable to get up. The captain sends her food and asks about her well-being as the sea grows heavier.

entries.fullText:
3d morn'g - Ship Idaho -
Terribly rough
sea all last night -
- could not sleep for
the feeling that evey
swell might end the
ships struggle - Had the
feeling all night that
I was much nearer to
Father, Ann Eliza, Thomas
King and he loved ones
beyond than to Mother
& all on this side
the great River -
entirely out of sight
of land all this time -
ship awfully slow -
not making over six miles
an hour -

Got out on deck
a little - ate only gruel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is on a ship called Idaho and is having a rough time sleeping due to the rough sea. She feels closer to her deceased father and loved ones than to her mother and those on the ship.

entries.fullText:
4th A. M. - ship Idaho -
The same pitching
down the great ocean
swells all the night
long - the same
unbounded waste
of deep blue surging
waters all the day -
- but some lightening
up of the sea
sickness -
Found several
pleasant people - Mrs
Mosby - Mrs Invers -
Mr Croft Bolles -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is still on the ship Idaho and is experiencing the same rough sea. She meets some pleasant people named Mrs. Mosby, Mrs. Invers, and Mr. Croft Bolles.

entries.fullText: Fifth day on ship Idaho - Capt. Floyd - quite steady this A. M. but too late for breakfast - so took cracker & Gruel & tomatoes - had long talk with Quackenbush of Davenport Iowa on woman question & social evil - he furnished tea & teapot & spirit lamp & the alcohol - & I treated Capt. table with delicious tea - first palatable drink - - at 8 Capt. took me to his room with Mrs Capt, Bowles, Gen Dyer & to Coffee - he showed me his maps & charts & explained Capts duties -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has a long talk with Quackenbush on woman question & social evil and enjoys a delicious tea with Capt. Floyd, Mrs. Capt. Bowles, and Gen Dyer on ship Idaho.

entries.fullText: Sixth morning on ship Idaho - First word - bar in sight - Cape Disappointment & Lighthouse - passed at 8.30 = shores beautful Columbia River ditto - 14 miles wide - all faces bright & cheery - & many new ones not seen before since first day - arrived Portland at 10 evening - & up the Willamette - large branch of the Columbia - glad enough to touch foot on land again -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Portland after enjoying the beautiful shores of Columbia River on ship Idaho.

entries.fullText: slept soundly till 8 A. M. - Mrs A. J. Dunniway called at 10. She takes lecture business agency at % gross receipts - pleasant face - everything rolling as on shipboard- P. M. Murphy of Herald formerly of the N.Y. World called Rev T. L. Eliot. saw Rev. Dr. Eliot - St. Louis & pastor of Unitarian Church here called - engaged to tea 4th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony slept soundly until 8 A.M. in St. Charles Hotel in Portland, Oregon. She met with Mrs. A. J. Dunniway who takes lecture business agency at % gross receipts. P. M. Murphy of Herald formerly of the N.Y. World called Rev T. L. Eliot. saw Rev. Dr. Eliot - St. Louis & pastor of Unitarian Church here called - engaged to tea 4th.

entries.fullText: Jeemes Pipes of Pipersville - Stephen Makett called - wrote letters to mother, Stanton, Collins, Stevens, Schenck, etc - trying to settle upon points for first speech -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Jeemes Pipes of Pipersville and Stephen Makett. She wrote letters to mother, Stanton, Collins, Stevens, Schenck, etc, trying to settle upon points for first speech.

entries.fullText:
Breakfast at 9.00 -
Unitarian Church -
Rev. T. L. Eliot - Text
Whither comest thou
and goest thou?
Pleasant - reminding
me of the dear departed
Rev. Samil J. May -
Read Godbe's Polygamy
lecture - Woodhulls
Capital & Labor speech -
& the weekly & cut,
& planned for speech
Dined at 5 and
took ride with Mr &
Mrs Duniway - then
read again till 10 -
& to bed - with thought
of Mother & all the loved
on both sides the big river -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Unitarian Church service and spends time with friends in Portland, Oregon.

entries.fullText:
Tea at Rev T. L. Eliots
called for at 6 -
[Mrs Eliot called]
Pleasant hour at
Mr Eliots -
Letters from Mrs
M. P. Sawtell - Salem Or -
& Mrs Carrie F. Young -
John L. Stephens -
Capt _ Dowles - arrived
at midnight - but
brought no letters
from San Francisco
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has tea with Rev T. L. Eliot and receives letters from acquaintances in Salem and San Francisco while in Portland, Oregon.

entries.fullText:
several calls
during day - Mrs
Young at Mrs Duniway
- Mrs D. accompanied
me to Rev T. L. Eliots
Reception at 8 P.M.
- saw many excellent
people - learned from
Mrs Victor that Mrs
Williams formerly of
Buffalo lives here -
entries.summaryText: Attended a reception and saw many excellent people in Portland.

entries.fullText:
First Lecture in
Oro Fino Hall - Power of Ballot - Mormon Suffrage
Never dreaded,
trembled so at prospect
before - fear of the Press
skinning me alive again
as did street of San Francisco
- But audience splendid
- made clear statement
& argument - but was
not free as I could wish
took one hour & 20 minutes
- Mrs Lillie Duniway[?] sang song
composed by her Mother -
Mrs D. introduced me -
with hope I wait
the mornings papers -
entries.summaryText: Gave a lecture on the power of ballot and Mormon suffrage in Portland, which was well received by the audience.

entries.fullText:
& Oregonian speak
well of lecture - the
Herald says it failed
to interest the audience.
- which means the
boy they sent to take
notes - I know
I had the audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Portland, Oregon which was well received by the Portland Bulletin and Oregonian newspapers, but the Herald reported that it failed to interest the audience.

entries.fullText:
2d Lecture - subject -
14 & 15 amendments -
Oro Fino Hall
Large audience
had pretty fun
time -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a second lecture in Portland, Oregon on the 14th and 15th amendments at Oro Fino Hall to a large audience who had a fun time.

entries.fullText:
shivering over
next lecture to
women alone this
P.M. - Free admission
- 400 women - very
carnest & intersted
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is nervous about her upcoming lecture to women only in Portland, Oregon. She reports that 400 women attended and were very interested.

entries.fullText:
Small & stupid
audience -
At rephrase next
Prof. Jo Lanez
the Astrologist at
Dr. Thomson's - & he
gave Horiscope of my
life from date of
6.30 - P.M. Feb 15, 1820
- & hit when a gavel my
points of past - good start
Jupiter rules from this to
1875 - then Saturn - Evil
fellow causes one [?]
& look out for Venus -
Ill in /75 (Mother in /73 -
[?] in /91 - probably)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reports on a small and uninterested audience at her lecture in East Portland, Oregon. She then recounts a visit to an astrologist who gave her a horoscope of her life, including predictions about the influence of Jupiter, Saturn, and Venus.

entries.fullText:
earliest settlement
of the State larger
manufactory of [?]
good here - [?]
rose blankets
good audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Oregon City, the earliest settlement of the state, and notes the presence of a large manufactory and good audience.

entries.fullText:
Clara Dunning & self
accepted invitation
to Mrs Bella I. Cooks -
Mrs Joaquin Miller
and girl child of
7 years there -
Joaquin Miller
the Poet - took all
the earnings of himself
& wife - left three children
and wife destitute and
went to England - &
now comes home with
published poems &
famous - a sad
story that of Mrs Miller
if true - & it seems so -
good audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Salem, Oregon where she and Clara Dunning accepted an invitation to Mrs. Bella I. Cook's home. She notes the presence of Mrs. Joaquin Miller and her 7-year-old daughter. She also writes about Joaquin Miller, the poet, who left his wife and three children destitute and went to England. He has now returned with published poems and fame. Susan expresses sadness for Mrs. Miller's story and notes the presence of a good audience.

entries.fullText:
2 P.M. - large
audience to women
alone - Social & with
evening large audience
again - but I was
not in best of trim[?]
still people seemed satisfied
The entire
Supreme Court
called on me
at Hotel - Judge
Lawson introducing
them -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a large audience in Salem, OR, including the entire Supreme Court who called on her at the hotel.

entries.fullText:
Seth Leweling
Desperately small
audience in a
school house -
Mrs D. went
home - Clara
stopped
Mr. L[?]
has most splendid
nursery & fruit
moved here in 1850 -
brother in 1847 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a small audience in Milwaukie, OR and visits with acquaintances including Seth Leweling and Mr. L who has a splendid nursery and fruit.

entries.fullText:
Left - Milwaukie -
Seth Lewelling at
noon - wife Mrs Clarissa
Lewelling -
Strict vegetable diet
& no tea, coffee, spices
or salt - St Charles
Hotel - Portland at
1 P.M. - Letters from
home - good news - save
little Harry trouble teething
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Milwaukie and met with Seth Lewelling and his wife Mrs Clarissa Lewelling. They had a strict vegetable diet and no tea, coffee, spices or salt. They stayed at St Charles Hotel in Portland and received good news from home about little Harry's teething.

entries.fullText:
Left St Charles Portland
at 4.30 - Henry fog -
Boat waited until 9 A.M.
pleasant day - but
did not reach The
Dalles until 8 P.M.
had 100 people -
Slept at Umatilla
House -
met Mrs
Elizabeth Miller
Wilson -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left St Charles Portland and met with Mrs Elizabeth Miller Wilson. They slept at Umatilla House and arrived at The Dalles at 8 P.M. after a pleasant day with 100 people on the boat.

entries.fullText:
Left The Dalles - 5 A.M.
R.R. 14 miles round
rapids & falls - then
steamer Tenino to
Umatilla Landing -
where laid up for night
Went on shore
took glass of Angelica
wine with Fred. Lalade
- Umatilla Or - an
Old Bach. & talkative -
Capt. Strumph invited
Mrs D. & self to Pilot house
to see river - took
good sleep before dinner
& again after dinner -
Boat laid up at
Umatilla over night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from The Dalles to Umatilla Landing, where she meets with Fred. Lalade and Captain Strumph.

entries.fullText:
arrived Wallula
landing at 9 A.M.
took stage for Walla Walla
Driver Amos Bradley
son of Amos Bradley
of Dansville N.Y. a
paper manufacturer
- ran away from home
at 14 & never have back
since - nor written
his mother - his mother
is married to Chatwich
of Avon - driver has
not drinked a drop
of whiskey since 1863 -
a whole souled fellow
Stopped at The
Oriental Hotel - at
Walla Walla -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Wallula landing and takes a stagecoach to Walla Walla, where she stays at The Oriental Hotel and meets Amos Bradley, a paper manufacturer who ran away from home at 14 and has not seen his mother since.

entries.fullText:
- Washington Teritory Fair
- new school House. Visit, - DIst. 34 -
- Oriental Hotel. Cook
- City Hall engaged to the
Pixley sisters - Theatricals -
beautiful girls - 18.16.12 -
Annie, Minnie, Lucy - manage
their own business & hire men
to fill up plays.
Had house packed -
but the help could not go
so far out of town - any
who did go couldn't get in.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Washington Teritory Fair, a new school house, and the Oriental Hotel in Walla Walla. She engages the Pixley sisters for theatricals and notes that they manage their own business and hire men to fill up plays. The house was packed but the help could not go so far out of town - any who did go couldn't get in.

entries.fullText:
City Hall - 2 P.M. to
women alone.
Mrs Annie Mix
Mrs H.P. Isaacs
Evening at new school House
again.
Small audience
too far out of town
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting at City Hall for women only with Mrs. Annie Mix and Mrs. H.P. Isaacs. In the evening, she goes to the new school house again but the audience is small due to it being too far out of town.

entries.fullText: Exchange Hall - Had fine audience & cleaned up the W.S. coast Free Love and all to satisfaction of Rev. Mr. Kimball & the friends - Dined with Mrs H. P. Isaacs - the Miller - has new & fine house & splendid orchard & fruits of every kind -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a successful speech in Walla Walla and dined with Mrs. H. P. Isaacs.

entries.fullText: Mr & Mrs T. J. Peabody not so hard ride back from W.W. on stage - small audience there - Mr P. is Wells Fargo's express agent - they have taken the Revolution from the very first -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a small audience in Wallula and met with Mr. & Mrs. T. J. Peabody who are supporters of the Revolution.

entries.fullText:
Had very small
audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a very small audience in The Dalles - Or - Empire Hotel on September 25, 1871.

entries.fullText:
Rev. Thomas Condon of
Dalles City - Congregrational Church
great naturalist - used
to know Beriah Green
Gerit Smith. Wm Goodell - P. C.
Jackson & all Abolitionists -
went to Mrs Dr
M. A. Thomsons - found
her ill - took tea & then
back to St Charles
fully resolved never
again to accept private
invitation in Oregon
entries.summaryText: On September 26, 1871, Susan B. Anthony met with Rev. Thomas Condon, a great naturalist who used to know Beriah Green, Gerit Smith, Wm Goodell, P. C. Jackson, and all Abolitionists. They went to visit Mrs. Dr. M. A. Thomsons, who was ill, and then back to St. Charles. Susan B. Anthony fully resolved never again to accept private invitation in Oregon.

entries.fullText:
Left St Charles
Portland at 8.30 A.M.
arrived Albany 4 P.M.
Hotels both full - at
last got room at Mr.
Fred Hill's -
Had fair audience
no dead heads seemingly
Dunniways give no tickets
unless pushed every time -
was very happy in
speech -
Mrs. Dunninway
came at eve - brought
letter from Sister
Mary & one from brother
Merritt dated Sept 8th -
poor J.M. miserable - all
write him to go Rochester
& rest & recruit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Albany, Oregon for the Linn Co. Fair. She had a fair audience and was happy with her speech. Mrs. Dunninway brought letters from Sister Mary and Merritt. J.M. is miserable and everyone is writing him to go to Rochester to rest and recruit.

entries.fullText:
Went to Hotel for
Breakfast - [?] tea total failure
Dined at Mrs
McCord's - then rode
up to Fair grounds -
in nothingness surpassed
only by the
Walla Walla Fair -
Had smaller
audience to night -
Dunniways so sure
of their old home - but
I find much dislike
to them & my audiences
suffer from it - Secrecy
impossible to escape fired by somebody being [sacri?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the fairgrounds after a failed breakfast at the hotel. She had a smaller audience that night and noticed dislike towards the Dunniways, which affected her audience. She also mentioned something about secrecy and someone being fired.

entries.fullText: Spoke in Mr Dave Long's Circus Tent on Fair Ground at 11 A.M. - hard work but crowd of free admission women & babies - In evening heard Mrs J. B. Frost - against W. S. - the weakest silliest acting & talking woman I ever saw - fairly dirty in her insinuations - Took 6 P.M. Dinner with large party at Mrs Fosters - splendid -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at a circus tent in Albany, Oregon, and later attended a dinner party at Mrs. Foster's. She also heard Mrs. J.B. Frost speak against W.S.

entries.fullText: At Wm. McCords - wife Harriet Scott - sister of Mrs Dunning- Studied up the objections & answers had a fine audience and brushed away the cobwebs - Mrs. D. went home in A.M. Mrs Foster's dinner was really the first square meal in Oregon -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Wm. McCord's and had a successful audience. She also mentions Mrs. Foster's dinner being the first square meal in Oregon.

entries.fullText: Studied up points for Temperance Lecture all the A.M. and spoke at 2 1/2 P.M. to a large audience in the Court House - was pretty well satisfied with my effort - told them never could succeed until woman was free in person & possessed of conscience & wisdom not to stunt children with appetites stronger than morals & intellects. In evening heard Rev Mr. Butcher against woman suffrage
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a Temperance Lecture in Albany, Oregon and speaks about the importance of women's freedom and their role in raising children. She also attends a speech against woman suffrage by Rev Mr. Butcher in the evening.

entries.fullText: Sent home check of gold $150. - making in all since coming into Oregon - one month $415. $320 in S.J. Bank = $735. gold - $150 in R. Bank - makes $975.20 in greenbacks not yet from four months hard work enough to pay Stillman Price: & Int. $2,100.00 Mr Ashby Pearce & invalid wife took me Albany to Corvallis - - Judge Cheneworth introduced me a large audience - but only $18 my half of the cash - Mr
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sends a check home and calculates her earnings since coming to Oregon. She also travels to Corvallis with Mr Ashby Pearce and attends a speech where she is only paid $18 for her efforts.

entries.fullText:
City Hotel - Johnson's
Presbyterian Church
2nd evening -
Mr Ashby Pearce &
wife left for home - Albany -
-Feel most terribly
blue - can it be some
evil to the loved ones
at home or in Kansas -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about feeling blue and wondering if something bad has happened to her loved ones in Kansas or at home in Corvallis, Oregon after Mr. Ashby Pearce and his wife left for home in Albany.

entries.fullText:
Chapel - Christian College
Mr R. V. Butler -
old New Hampshire
Democrat - rode
25 miles Corvallis to
Monmouth - had
fine audience -
Mr & Mrs
came 10 miles to
hear me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Chapel of Christian College in Monmouth, Oregon and has a fine audience. Mr. R. V. Butler, an old New Hampshire Democrat, rode 25 miles from Corvallis to Monmouth to hear her speak. Mr. & Mrs. also came 10 miles to hear her speak.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at Hotel -
Rev. M. Wood -
small audience -
Drove to Mr John
Gowdy's to dinner -
thence to Dayton
in P.M. - three
miles from mouth of
Yamhill River - empties
into Willamette -
Mrs S. did not
meet us here as
expected -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at a hotel and had dinner with Rev. M. Wood and Mr. John Gowdy. She then went to Dayton and Mrs. S. did not meet them as expected.

entries.fullText:
Staid in bed at
Hotel Dayton till 12 -
noon - then Mr D. came
& took me to Mrs Ds sister
Fanny's - Amos Book's - good
farmers near Lafayette to
Dinner - then in P.M.
across Yamhill River, ferry
to younger sisters Sarah
Maria - J. M. Kelty's
had large audience -
dead headed largely -
still people came
14 & 15 miles
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed in bed until noon at Hotel Dayton. She then had dinner with Mr. D., Mrs. D's sister Fanny, and Amos Book. In the afternoon, she went to Sarah Maria's and had a large audience.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in immensely
long narrow unfinished
hall - large audience
Stopped at Mrs
Talmadge - Widow
Husband left her
taking most of property
with five children
& has another young
wife in California
Marriage here
is practically anything
but an indissoluble tie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a large audience in McMinnville, Oregon. She stayed with Mrs. Talmadge, a widow with five children whose husband left her and has another wife in California.

entries.fullText:
Took stage at
6 A. M. - 20 miles
to Forest Grove -
arrived at Mr
J. T. Scotts at noon -
pleasant man
proud of his family
of daughters -
Driver told of
a woman who had
six children &
six living husbands -
now keeping hotel
to support self & children
without a man -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Forest Grove, Oregon and stayed with Mr. J. T. Scotts. The stagecoach driver told a story of a woman with six children and six living husbands who is now supporting herself and her children by running a hotel.

entries.fullText:
John T. Scott
Mrs Dunniway's Father -
Had fine audience
- some boys threw
Cayenne Pepper on
the hot stove in Congregational
Church
It made a terrific
coughing - & almost
stopped me from
speaking - Dr. Marsh
& all the College
faculty dreadfully mortified -
probably some of
their bad city boys-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a fine audience in Forest Grove, Oregon, but is almost stopped from speaking due to boys throwing cayenne pepper on the hot stove in the Congregational Church.

entries.fullText:
Visited the college
Dr. Marsh Presid.
Took stage at noon
arrived Portland 5.30
P.M. - Corderoy road
six miles down the
mountain -
Stopped St. Charles
found letters from home
Sept 20 & 21 - all well -
Brother Merritt no better
Caller Dr. M.A. Thomsons
T.L. Eliots -This
A. M. Telegram brought
word of Chicago fire - 4
miles in length & 2 miles
in width - Dear Aunt
A.E.D. probably burned
at stove if not worse-
[?] Splendid view of Mt. Hood
at Helens & Jefferson -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the college and Dr. Marsh in Portland, receives letters from home, and hears news of the Chicago fire. She also enjoys a splendid view of Mt. Hood at Helens and Jefferson.

entries.fullText:
At St Charles Hotel -
decided to take good A.M.
sleep & go on P.M. train - & lo
there is no P.M. train -
So wrote letters with
might & main - sent home
$100. gold check - making in all
$500. from Oregon - five weeks
lectures - wrote dear
Aunt A. E. Dickinson -
- The Chicago fire terrible
Mrs. Dunning has
engaged Salem Court
House - very few went
& no meeting
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her stay at St Charles Hotel in Salem, Oregon, and how she had to write letters instead of taking a train. She also mentions the Chicago fire and Mrs. Dunning's engagement.

entries.fullText:
Up at 5.15 - breakfast
and off at 7 A.M. -
- Immense crowd
of people & tents - every
body from all parts of
the state come & camp
out whole week -
spoke in Ryland's Circus
Tent. 100 people - but good
ones - got 18 autographs
& dollars for National
Committee - Mrs D. about
as many subscribers -
- Camped with
the D's this night - the first
time in life Mr. D -[?]
Kelly - 3 boys - Clara Mrs. D.
& self - packed side by
side like herrings - can't
say I like it better than
nice bedroom & hair matress -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Ryland's Circus Tent and camps with the D's, getting autographs and subscribers for the National Committee.

entries.fullText: Mrs. J. D. Fort spoke against W.S. in Circus tent - not over 210 persons - Col. Taggart gave annual agricultural address - saw slab-sided spinster - failed to get a whole [man?] east on [way?] [?] to Salt Lake to try for a fraction of one. I spoke some stand in in P.M. to fully 1000. & was happy in a real Patrick Henry speech -
entries.summaryText: Attended the State Fair in Salem, heard speeches by Mrs. J. D. Fort and Col. Taggart, saw a spinster, and gave a speech to 1000 people.

entries.fullText: Went to city to Judge Geo. W. Lawson's - dined & read of Pioneer & the Rev - sent $37 P.O. order to N.W.S. Committee - & $25. to Aunt A.E.D. - I only wished it could have been $100 as a token of my thought of their great loss - Took train at 5 P.M. & returned Portland - St. Charles - A lot of coarse men talked to me & I answered seriously & severly in ears - & was sorry I did
entries.summaryText: Visited Judge Geo. W. Lawson, sent money to the N.W.S. Committee and Aunt A.E.D., and returned to Portland while dealing with unwanted attention from men.

entries.fullText:
Called at Mrs D's - she
not home yet - riding
in carriage - talked
with Isaac Lowry - he's
head printer, local
editor - fine young man
& promising - too delicate
& sensitive - fine
warm day - a
few showers of
nights - no mud yet -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. D's home in Portland and talks with Isaac Lowry, a head printer and local editor.

entries.fullText:
Took steamer at
6 A.M. down Willamette -
down Columbia to Cowlitz
- Monticello - then stage
25 miles to Pumphrey's
awful roads - [called]
Telegraph asking day
at Olympia changed -
consented, said make
Fee $1. and give over third
gross receipts to Chicago -
- Ate fried mountain
trout for supper &
dreamed most
uncomfortably all night
to 2 1/2 when came
call to be up & off
for Olympia -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a steamer and stagecoach to Olympia, encountering bad roads and dreaming uncomfortably.

entries.fullText:
Pumphreys - took
stage at 3 A.M.
Dark Dark - Lanterns
only to see by - rode
14 miles walking every
step to breakfast -
then 18 to dinner -
dreadful roads &
long mountains -
passengers all walked
miles of it - from
last station fine road
30 miles - Mr
Manning met us & took
me to his house - in
double quick time took
hot bath & was in bed -
had small audience -
but went through with
speech - scarce a man
could have done it after
such a ride
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes her difficult journey to Olympia, Washington Territory and giving a speech to a small audience.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Judge
Bigelows - his wife
splendid - met several
members of Legislature -
- voluntary vote waiting
me to address Legislature
tomorrow 2 P.M.
Letter from E. Pitts
Stevens telling of my
lack of cooperation with
her & her Pioneer - One
from L. D. Gordon to
attend Con. Sacramento -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dines with Judge Bigelows and receives a letter from E. Pitts Stevens and L. D. Gordon.

entries.fullText:
Addressed Legislature
at 2 P.M. Assembly
Room packed -
Made pretty good
argument -
Dined
with Mrs Phillip
J. Moore - got
[?] & cranberry
on gray silk - awfully
provoking -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony addressed the Legislature in Olympia Wash Ter and had dinner with Mrs Phillip J. Moore.

entries.dateText:
OCTOBER
20 Friday
Tum water - Wash Ter
entries.fullText:
Mrs Martha Tower
Very small audience
Invited to amend Judge
DiGelouis bill on suffrage
lost by 16 to 11 - not
considered a test vote
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a small audience in Tum water - Wash Ter and Mrs Martha Tower lost by 16 to 11 in an attempt to amend Judge DiGelouis bill on suffrage.

entries.fullText:
had big house
answered objections
& [made?] [them?]
[ring?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a big house and answered objections.

entries.fullText:
Wrote letters home
to [Pills'y?] - Pioneer
& to Mother, D.R.,
& Merritt -
not a line yet
from Mrs Stanton
Mrs Case - daughter
of Mrs Tower of Rochester
called & took me
to her school house -
Took Steamer at
10 P.M. for Astoria
- Vancouver Island
so near Victoria's
kingdom -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote letters and met with Mrs Case, daughter of Mrs Tower of Rochester. She then took a steamer to Vancouver Island.

entries.fullText:
arrived at
3 P.M. - met Mr
D. at boat - rain
pouring - Branch
Colonia Hotel -
small audience
not over 100 -
& not one then
women -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Victoria - V.I. and met Mr D. at the boat. She stayed at the Branch Colonia Hotel and spoke to a small audience of not over 100 people, none of whom were women.

entries.fullText:
Alhambra Hall
Small audience
but a few were
women not a
dozen though -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Alhambra Hall in Victoria - V.I. to a small audience, but only a few were women, not even a dozen.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Tucker
had about 100
but not more than
10 women -
Told them I had
been told people were
unused to very [?]
every thing but negro
dances etc - therefore
I would try free
admission tomorrow
night -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Tucker had a group of about 100 people, mostly men, and Susan B. Anthony suggested trying free admission the next night.

entries.fullText:
Peter Lester (colonel) - formerly
of Philadelphia - knew
Lucretia Mott, Sarah Pugh etc. -
Mrs M. J. Hamilton, Colorado, widow
[?] H. Francis -
Mrs Lydna E. R. Francis
Mrs Washington
Had free admission
& packed
house - though it rained
Made tip top speech
But still nearly
all men - not
20 women
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a speech to a packed house of mostly men, despite free admission and heavy rain. She mentions several people she met, including Peter Lester, Lucretia Mott, and Mrs. M.J. Hamilton.

entries.fullText:
Left Victoria at
[3 P.M.] noon - arrived
at Port Townsend
at 3 P.M. -
No Lecture this
evening - But too
much upset with
rough sea to
write -
Walked with
Mrs D. down to the
Indian huts & there
saw boys perfectly
naked - & eating
clams out of shells
for spoons
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Port Townsend from Victoria and walks with Mrs. D. to see naked boys eating clams.

entries.fullText:
Port Townsend - Wash. Ter.
Phillip D. Moore
John Burns - formerly of
Danversport - Mass. - friend
of Parker Pillsbury -
Dr Thomas T. Minor
of Col. Higginsons Regiment &
assistant surgeon with Cousin
Dr. Seth Rogers.
Had fair audience
Mr Moore introduced
me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has a fair audience in Port Townsend and is introduced by Mr. Moore.

entries.fullText:
Took little sail
boat across to
Coupeville at
9 A.M. - went
to Capt Coupes
house - had good
meeting
Mrs Caroline Kellog
Mrs. A. N. Dean
two splendid
wide awake women
entries.summaryText: Meeting with Mrs Caroline Kellog and Mrs. A. N. Dean in Coupeville.

entries.fullText:
Left Coupeville
at 11 A.M. - Mr
Greer Methodist
minister came over
to Port Townsend -
gave objections -
- the stench of
something dreadful
kills the life in
me - Letters from
Sister Mary & Mrs
Stanton - latter pretty
scolding about San
Francisco 320 check
I failed to get off -
entries.summaryText: Received objections from Mr Greer in Port Townsend and letters from Sister Mary and Mrs Stanton about San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
Left Port Townsend
at 3 P.M. - worked
on speech up to
last minute -
arrived Seattle
7:20 - went to
Occidental Hotel -
hard enough -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Port Townsend and arrived at Seattle's Occidental Hotel after working on a speech.

entries.fullText:
Seattle - Wash. Ter.
Mary O. Brown
Mr Dunaway went
home - [I to Hotel]
Mrs Wiggins came
for me & I went
with her - & a
splendid change
it was too -
Good audience
though I was
not in best mood -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Mary O. Brown and Mrs. Wiggins in Seattle and gave a speech to a good audience despite not being in the best mood.

entries.fullText:
- Several calls
in A.M. - Dinner
at 5 at Mr
Suras Browns -
wife a sister of
Eliz. Peebles - the
Enrolling clerk last
year -
Had large
audience - Mr
Wiggins tended
door - all said
I made good speech
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had several calls in Seattle, had dinner at Mr. Suras Browns with a large audience and made a good speech.

entries.fullText:
- Mr Harry Wiggins
Sent check at $7 to
Mrs Stanton - with
the $640 San Francisco
certificate to A.M. McLean
Meeting in P.M.
at Dr. Bugleys church
and society [???]
Mrs Jesler President -
Then to dinner
with Mrs Sarah B.
Jesler - & then
back to Mrs Wiggins -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a check from Mr Harry Wiggins and sent it to Mrs Stanton along with a certificate from San Francisco. She attended a meeting at Dr. Bugleys church and had dinner with Mrs Sarah B. Jesler before returning to Mrs. Wiggins.

entries.fullText:
- Went
to forlorn hotel -
3 babies & Irish mother
in sitting room & no
other fire - dreary
prospect for Sunday -
But Mr Meiggs
came & took me to
his home - & the
minute I entered I
felt it was a haven
of rest - to me -
Rev. Mr. Damon introduced
me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Seattle to Port Madison and stays at a forlorn hotel before being taken in by Mr. Meiggs who provides her with a haven of rest.

entries.fullText:
Geo. A. Meiggs -
Delightful home
- large fire place -
Mrs Edwards Miss
Ordway & others
took me through new
ship built here by
Mill Co. 'Wild Wood'
splendid - Then out
on a hill & there I
saw Mount Rainier -
(Tacoma) - and several
lower peaks of the
Cascades - beautiful
Spoke in evening -
good audience -
Mr Wiggs attended
both lectures - rare honor
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the delightful home of Geo. A. Meiggs and sees the new ship built by Mill Co. She also sees Mount Rainier and several lower peaks of the Cascades. She speaks in the evening to a good audience and Mr. Wiggs attends both lectures, which is a rare honor.

entries.fullText:
Left Port Madisin
at six A.M. arrived
Port Gamble - at 9 -
Mrs. John Seavy met us
at wharf & insisted
we should go with her -
- She had nice new
house - & did every thing
for our comfort - but
just before starting for lecture
her husband came in &
said he didn't keep
hotel - that his wife had
no right to invite us &c -
- Representative Garfield
introduced me - small
audience - & very poor
speech - cold house
& generally disagreeable tri[p?]
went to Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Port Gamble, meets Mrs. John Seavy who invites her to stay at her house, but later her husband says they cannot stay. Representative Garfield introduces her at a small lecture.

entries.fullText:
Congressman Garfield
called - hasn't thought
upon question - guess
the women will
wake him up soon -
Took steamer
at 6:20 P.M. for
Olympia -
Mrs. Seavy called -
but cant get over
a woman's inviting
guests. Then so [?]
allowing them to be sent
off by her husband
entries.summaryText: Congressman Garfield visits and Susan B. Anthony takes a steamer to Olympia. Mrs. Seavy calls and is still upset about the previous day's events.

entries.fullText:
Territorial W. S. Convention
Steamer late - 10 Oclock
went to Mrs. [Mannings ?]
took cup of coffee &
then to Olympia Hall -
quite a little gathering
though raining hard -
larger in P.M. and
in evening packed -
Mrs. J. D. Frost refused
invitation to speak as
an insult -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Territorial W. S. Convention in Olympia, Washington. Mrs. J. D. Frost refuses to speak as an insult.

entries.fullText:
W.T.W.S. Convention
Raining all day still
- got society organized
- Mrs Amelia
Giddings President -
packed house again
in evening - [?] David
serenaded me
at 10:20 - Capt Hale
a rich widower at
bottom of it - alas
alas poor soul -
to bed at 11 to be
called by Policeman
at 1:30 A.M. -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the W.T.W.S. Convention in Olympia, Washington. Mrs. Amelia Giddings is elected President. [?] David serenades Susan B. Anthony and Capt Hale, a rich widower, is at the bottom of it. Susan B. Anthony is called by a Policeman at 1:30 A.M.

entries.fullText:
Left Olympia at
2 Oclock A.M. - rode
30 miles to Half Way
House to Breakfast -
18 to McDonalds to
Dinner - 14 to Pumphreys
to sleep - & such a
pounding - took hot
baths & supperless to
bed by 7 - to be routed
at 2 A.M. again -
slept soundly -
But the log
road beats all
hard jolting yet
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Olympia to Pumphreys, describing the journey and the rough log road.

entries.fullText:
Called at 2.30 A.M.
and on stage at 3 - 9
miles dark, rain & mud
to Jackson's to breakfast -
then 13 to Monticello
to dinner & Steamer
[Gunnie ?] Troupe at 1 P.M.
for Portland - the
roughest road ever
known -
Found letters from
Stanton, Stillman, Mr
Stevens, Mrs Giffins
&c - & got Revolutions
Journals and read
up Eastern news -
American W.S. hold
Con. at Washington Dec 8th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Monticello to Portland, reading letters and news on the way.

entries.fullText: - slept until late - & then Mrs Duniway's read up papers &c - Mrs Dr. Thomson came in - then back Hotel. - wrote letters to Mrs. Stanton - fear her Gerritt or Hattie are gone from her a sad feeling for her all day - wrote Mary, Aaron & T. W. Stillman - pay him $1140. - wrote Mrs L. [?] Force Gordon
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about sleeping in and reading papers before writing letters to Mrs. Stanton, Mary, Aaron, T. W. Stillman, and Mrs L. [?] Force Gordon. She also mentions feeling sad for Mrs. Stanton, who fears that Gerritt or Hattie are gone from her.

entries.fullText: Spent A. M. writing - P. M. with Dr. Thomson calling on women to sign call for meeting to organize big W. S. association -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the morning writing and the afternoon with Dr. Thomson calling on women to sign a call for a meeting to organize a big W. S. association.

entries.fullText:
Rained, rained, actually
poured all the day -
30 Ladies or so met at
Orofino Hall & formed
a W. S. association of
the very best position
too - Mrs. H R. Williams
made a long visit
entries.summaryText: 30 ladies met at Orofino Hall and formed a W.S. association.

entries.cityOrState:
Portland - Oro Fino Hall
St. Charles Hotel
entries.fullText:
Dark & [lowry ?] but no rain -
terrible depression of
spirit with feeling of impossibility
to make this last
speech in Portland -
if the fact matches the
feeling - small audiences-
and not one second's
lighting up of the brain -
the barest, boldest points
& no thought beyond -
altogether, it was & is the
most terrible experience
of my life of trying, of being
compellent to speak when
the spirit said nothing
but no, no. - Mrs. Harriet
Mrs. Williams, formerly of Buffalo,
N.Y. introduced me & 6 or 8
Ladies on platform -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a terrible experience giving a speech in Portland with small audiences and no inspiration.

entries.fullText:
Letter received from
A. T. Stevens - with
testimonial signed by
J.M. Fryer & Co.
John M. Breck
C.S. Silver
J.H. Mitchell
returned
the note of Mr. A. T. Stevens
Had calls from Mr
& Mrs O.B. Williams
Mrs. [?] & others -

sun shine to day -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter and testimonial from A. T. Stevens and had calls from Mr. and Mrs. O.B. Williams.

entries.cityOrState:
Portland - to Oregon City
Oregon City -
entries.fullText:
Dr. Mary. A. Thomson
Mrs Dick. Williams &
Mrs. Dunway - called before
I left for Oregon
Court House packed
& good speech again -
Mrs. Coburn up
with two neighbors
- walked full a mile
entries.summaryText: Met with Dr. Mary A. Thomson, Mrs. Dick Williams, and Mrs. Dunway before leaving for Oregon City. Gave a good speech at the Court House and walked a mile with Mrs. Coburn and two neighbors.

entries.fullText:
Left Oregon City
at 9 A.M. - found
no Mr Smith at
Salem to take me to
Buenavista - So jogged
on to Albany - then
stopped of, called at
Wm. McCords & Mrs MC
went with me to Mr
Foster's - Mrs F. down
with sick Head ache
but good visit & good
supper then 6. train
to Eugene City Hotel -
poor enough [for?] too
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Oregon City to Eugene City Hotel, stopping at various places along the way.

entries.fullText:
Got notices off to
the Churches - by
aid of Sheriff Mr -
Poindexter - & had
a packed Court
House this evening
Mr. J. H. D. Henderson
M.E. Hunter
good (careful) friend -
Free admission
and splendid
enthusiasm -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sends notices to churches and has a successful event at the Court House with the help of Sheriff Mr. Poindexter and the support of Mr. J. H. D. Henderson and M.E. Hunter.

entries.fullText:
Fine audience
again - but publisher
put admission down
to 25 cts -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a fine audience in Eugene, but the publisher reduces admission to 25 cents.

entries.fullText:
Left Eugene City
at 5 A.M. for
Oakland 60 miles
Driver John
good, fellow rode
outside part of way -
20 miles Corduroy road-
reached Oakland 10
P.M. tired enough -
supper & to bed - hard
little speck of room, in
corner of dining room &
foot of stairs & bar room -
thin cloth petition & perfectly
noisy -
Mrs Tibbetts a
motherly old lady
who gave me good cup
of coffee -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Eugene City to Oakland, encountering a rough road and arriving late at night to a noisy and uncomfortable room. She is grateful for the hospitality of Mrs. Tibbetts, who gives her a good cup of coffee.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in School
House - fine audience
James A. Sterling the
Post Master made
all arrangements -
James Wright, the
Driver - married Mrs. Wright
with several fine girls
& she Mrs W. [Thoray?]
bright & in [?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at a schoolhouse in Oakland, OR. James A. Sterling made all the arrangements. James Wright, the driver, married Mrs. Wright with several fine girls.

entries.fullText:
Left at 7 A.M. with
driver Tom of
Canyonville - rode
outside with Driver
reached Roseberg
& Mrs B. A. Owens
at 12 noon - she
is splendid married
& a mother at 12 / &
divorced before 18 -
- scarcely able to read -
- then hired room at
Astoria, went to District
school, took her five
year old boy with her - &
is now making $2000 [?]
at millinery & store here in
her own home -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Oakland to Roseberg with driver Tom of Canyonville. She met Mrs. B. A. Owens, who is a splendid married mother and divorced before 18. Mrs. Owens hired a room in Astoria, went to district school, took her five-year-old boy with her, and is now making $2000 at millinery and store in her own home.

entries.fullText:
- Had fair
audience last night
& fine ladies this A.M.
- Mrs Sarah Reaves
at Mrs Owens - widow in
Pa - her sister lived here
died & left five children
brother in law - widower
got her to come to take the
children back - for two
years tried every means
to make her marry him -
Strong Methodist - but
she resisted - & when
hope was gone he
turned her out of his
house penniless. She
is now married to a
good man - Left Roseberg
at 12 - noon -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a fair audience and met Mrs. Sarah Reaves in Roseberg. She learned about a widow who was turned out of her house penniless by her brother-in-law.

entries.fullText:
Reached Canyonville
& supped at 7 P.M. last
night - 25 miles - then
I had John Greene the
reformed gambler - for
dinner - real name
Bartlett of Adrian
Mich - rode on
outside 35 miles, bright
moonlight to start with -
but rain soon poured -
- had our Drivers water
proof coat over my own water proof - still
blankets got wet - got
inside last 10 miles driving to
[Grants] Pass - breakfasted
at 7 & off with Rising for
Driver - reached
Jacksonville at 2 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Roseberg to Canyonville and met John Greene, a reformed gambler. She then traveled to Grants Pass and Jacksonville with Rising as the driver.

entries.fullText:
and took hot bath &
went to bed - servant
brought to my bed steak
& baked potatoes - ate &
tried to sleep - but too
much noise & interruption
- scarcely lost myself -
at six up & dressed &
at M.E. Church at 7 -
Spoke 2 hours & then
back to Hotel - cold
& forlorn & in bed
by 10 - called at 3 A.M.
& off again at 4. for
Yreka Cal - arrived
at 6 P.M. - Supper
& to bed - E. Steele
called - best man
crossed Cisco range
this day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes her day, including speaking for two hours at M.E. Church and traveling to Yreka Cal.

entries.fullText:
Yreka - Cal
Hotel Clerk
Charlie LaBeau took
me out to see the
Shasta Bute peak -
rival of Mt. Hood,
Tacomah & Baker -
but the fog bank rested
down upon its head -
Splendid audience in
Court House E. Steele the
strongest W.S. man -
Mrs Jerome Churchill
called -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Shasta Bute peak and attends a speech by E. Steele in Court House.

entries.fullText:
quite a snow storm
no prospect of getting a
view of Shasta -
Meeting at 2. P.M.
large audience - stood
on feet & answered
questions put by the County
Superintendent Public school
Moffat - & a young man -
Dined with
Mrs Jerome Churchill
Mr Peck stage agent
paid me back $10.
of the $40. I paid at Eugene
Took stage again -
7 P.M. - fine moonlight
view of old Shasta Mt
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a meeting in Yreka, Cal with a large audience and dined with Mrs. Jerome Churchill and Mr. Peck. She also received a payment of $10 from Mr. Peck and took a stage again at 7 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Rode all last night
in stage, breakfast at
9 this A.M. - Splendid
Inn's view of Castle
Rock -- it is splendid -
rode through Sacramento
Canyon in very
fine day - & scenery
grand - splendid
views of old Shasta
too - stopped at 9 P.M.
& then was packed 9 in
short narrow waggon - most
dreadfully uncomfortable
- arrived Red Bluff
at 3 A.M. & stopped
at Fremont House
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony rode through Sacramento Canyon and saw splendid views of Castle Rock and old Shasta. She arrived at Red Bluff at 3 A.M. and stopped at Fremont House.

entries.fullText: Post Master - Made no arrangement for my meeting - Sheriff refused Court House got the Old School House - no fire in it - & spoke to a small audience - and Mrs called at 2.30 - Friday A.M. stage 12 miles to Takoma - then cars to Chico - Here I lost my nice rubber
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Red Bluffs, Or and speaks to a small audience in an Old School House.

entries.fullText: Post Master put letter in P.O. Box of Mr R.H. Allen - agent for Gen. Bidwell - owner of 22,000 acre land grant - - Mr Allen met me at Depot - & such a nice cup of coffe & cozy house as he & his good wife Emma gave me - Fine audience, though sever rain just at hour - Read up Revolutions - W.T. Clark Editor - everything so dreadfully manish
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mr R.H. Allen, owner of a 22,000 acre land grant, and speaks to a fine audience in Chico despite severe rain.

entries.fullText:
Theater Dawson Hotel -
small audience
but good People
[?] $20 -
the lecture - rotten
expense - the fates
have turned against
financial success
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture at the Theater Dawson Hotel in Marysville Cal to a small audience and received $20. She describes the lecture as 'rotten' and laments the lack of financial success.

entries.fullText:
Took train 10 A.M.
for Sacramento -
Laura DiForce Gorden
[?] Soc. women
met me at Depot -
Miss Jennie Phelps
& [?] son accompanied
me into San Francisco
Grand Hotel -
arrived at 8 P.M.
found a few letters
but Mrs Schenck
Monday A.M. brought
me 20 or 30 from
all quarters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled by train to Sacramento and was met by Laura DiForce Gorden and Miss Jennie Phelps. She arrived at the Grand Hotel in San Francisco and received several letters from Mrs. Schenck the following day.

entries.fullText:
Grand Hotel -
first call on Pitts
Stevens - she could not
give reason for Pioneer
not mentioning my names
the three months I have
been in Oregon & Wash. Ter. -
told her plainly - the
women of the state would
not support her paper
if she allowed it to be
the medium of the man's -
J.A. Collins - spite & spleen
- Mrs Schenck came -
called on Mrs Clark & saw
Grace Greenwood - then
home with Schenck -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits San Francisco and meets with Pitts Stevens. She confronts Stevens about not mentioning her name in the Pioneer newspaper and tells her that women of the state would not support her paper if she allowed it to be the medium of the man's. She also meets with Mrs. Schenck and Grace Greenwood.

entries.fullText:
Left Mrs Schencks
house at 9 - Gordon
Schenck - long talk with
Mrs D. Wolf - at 2
P.M. took boat for
Petaluma - found
no meeting advertised
but they had taken Friday
night - - Mrs A.A.
Huskell fully with
Mrs Stanton on marriage
& Divorce - Mrs Col Hatch
& Mrs Kate Res.
the Society called

at a later date
Mrs Haskell sent me
bills for advertising lectures
for Friday night - instead
of this Tuesday - rather cool -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Mrs. Schenck's house and has a long talk with Mrs. D. Wolf. She then takes a boat for Petaluma but finds no meeting advertised. She receives bills for advertising lectures for Friday night instead of Tuesday from Mrs. A.A. Huskell at a later date.

entries.fullText:
Left Petaluma - Mrs
A. A. Haskell - at
8 A. M. - arrived Grand
Hotel at 11.30 - Mr
Col. C.P. Hatch -
Mr P. Conen the
Post master -
Mr Spencer - of
Santa Rosa - Cal -
Mrs L. A. A. Harth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Petaluma to Grand Hotel, meeting several people along the way.

entries.fullText:
Left Grand Hotel at
8.30 Vallejo Route - arrived
Sac. noon - Capital Hotel -
Mrs Esther Curtis & Mrs
Gordon met me at Depot -
Small meeting in P.M.
Larger in evening - but
a very hard time to call
Convention - every
body full of getting
out & into office -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Sacramento and attends small and large meetings, but has a hard time calling a convention due to everyone being preoccupied with getting into office.

entries.fullText: Small meeting of friends in A.M. attended gov. Boothe's inauguration at 12 - good meeting in P.M. & evening Judge Palmer of Nevada City - avowed his platform for W. suffrage - though a Democrat, [?] against Republican not W.S.
entries.summaryText: Attended inauguration and meetings in Sacramento with friends and Judge Palmer advocating for women's suffrage.

entries.fullText: Left Sacramento on the 7.30 A.M. train arrived Grand Hotel at 12 noon - wrote letters Mrs Walton, Mrs Curtis & daughters, Miss Atkinson called - also Mrs. Prof. Case of Oakland accompanied her & Mr & Mrs J. M. Speare to Mechanics Institute to listen to Prof Carr's lecture on the Atmosphere - Wearisome - 500 hard working men, & ought to be entertainingly instructed
entries.summaryText: Traveled to Grand Hotel and attended a lecture at Mechanics Institute with Mrs. Prof. Case and Mr & Mrs J. M. Speare.

entries.fullText:
Went to Mayfield
with Mrs Schenck
this P.M. on 4 train
met warm welcome -
_______________
At meeting met she
that was Sybil [Acharna ?]
of Canajoharie - Mont. Co.,
N.Y - now wife of
D. Hoag - Mayfield [Cal?]
- Just the same little
progress, is Baptist member
- husband backed up carriage
to keep her from going to W.S.
lecture - but she seemed
very glad to see me & asked
any amount of questions of
the olden people of Canajo.
entries.summaryText: Met with Mrs. Schenck in Mayfield and attended a meeting where she saw Sybil, a Baptist member from Canajoharie who is now married to D. Hoag. Her husband backed up the carriage to keep her from going to a W.S. lecture.

entries.fullText:
Mayfield - Cal
Mrs. Sarah Wallis
Had pleasant day - Mrs
W. Owens large estate -
fine orchards & grounds
Large audience -
J.J. Owen Ed of San Jose
Mercury present - said
Miss A. you touch
bed rock every time.
Mrs McKee - Mrs
Knox, Mrs Matson,
a whole omnibus load
drove out from San Jose -
17 miles - Had song
by choir - Mrs Wallis two
beautiful daughters of
them - then Ball &
dance & supper at twelve
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Sarah Wallis in Mayfield and had a pleasant day. Attended a large meeting with J.J. Owen, Ed of San Jose Mercury present. Had a song by choir and then a ball, dance, and supper at twelve.

entries.fullText:
small meeting - &
dreadfully cold Hall -
large & bleak -
returned to San
Fran. Grand Hotel
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a small and cold meeting in Oakland with several people, including Jennie Phelps, Mary Perkins Randall, Mother Perkins Percy, and Mrs. Percy. They later returned to San Francisco Grand Hotel.

entries.fullText:
A fair audience
700 - but dead headed
mainly - made my
14th amendment argument
splendidly - all delighted
with it & me - and it is
such a comfort to have
the friends feel that I help
the good work on -
Wm. Rider - from Herkimer
Co. N. York - son of
Matthew Rider - gave best
help & is a genuine
friend of cause -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a fair audience of 700 people at Platts Hall in San Francisco, making a 14th amendment argument that was well received. She mentions that Wm. Rider, son of Matthew Rider from Herkimer Co. N. York, was a great help and a genuine friend of the cause.

entries.fullText: - got egg & cup of tea & rushed to Hall - The W.S. Society Pres Mrs Jewett & several ladies met me at Hotel - the hall awfully large & only a few people the man never consulted with the women - have nothing done ship shape - S. P. Myers & daughters & E. Lindsay rode up from Windsor six miles to hear me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Healdsburg, California and speaks to a small audience at a large hall.

entries.fullText: Took cars at 7 A.M. reached Hall at 12 noon - - L.D.F. Gordon speaking - splendid audience of all the divisions & subdivisions of the W.S. friends - In P.M. splendid meeting of women alone - Social Evil & Dr. Hollands Bill - all said I made splendid speech - Grand Hotel Reception at evening - about 80 persons - delightful company & social supper at 9 P.M. - Lena Clark - (Medium) said Gov. has such power this P.M. saw hosts of strong women around you - both Gordon & Phelps slept with me-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a large audience in San Francisco and attends a reception with other notable individuals.

entries.fullText:
- Left Grand Hotel
at 6.30 A. M - Miss
Jennie Phelps - the
'Hagar' of the Alta -
went to Boat with me
- Found Gordon there -
arrived Stockton 11 A. M.
- went to Hall almost
none there - evening
but little better -
Mrs Conde is
President of their society -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Grand Hotel to Stockton and meets with Jennie Phelps, Gordon, and Mrs. Conde.

entries.fullText:
- Took train at 11 A. M.
for Colfax - arrived
there 5.30 - Stage to
Nevada City - 12 miles -
passed Grass Valley 8 miles
from Colfax - 4 from
Nevada City - Found
Mrs Ellen C. Sargent , two
daughters & one son at the
National Exchange Hotel to
welcome me - A. A. Sargents
family - the new Senator from
California - Began to
rain at Grass Valley &
positively poured all
the evening & all night -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels by train to Colfax and then by stage to Nevada City where she meets with Mrs. Ellen C. Sargent and her family.

entries.fullText:
Rain poured all the
day & evening - about 40
people present - sent out
to teacher & others about
100 complimentary tickets
Mrs Judge Palmer
who got up meeting saw
on Saturday everybody
promised to attend - but
the storm bringing new
hope of harvests & life
to farmers & miners brought
empty benches to me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a meeting in Nevada City that was poorly attended due to a storm.

entries.fullText:
Took stage at
noon for Colfax.
The rain absolutely
pouring all the way -
San Fran. train behind
did not come until 11
night - went to Hotel
& tried to sleep but
failed in my effort -
took train at 11.20 -
woke up at Sacramento -
most terrible storm on
the San Fran. Bay - were
delayed along & did
not reach Reno until
11.30 Wednesday - at 1 P.M.
took stage (R.R. washed away)
to Steamboat Springs 12
miles - thence stage to
Virginia City -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes a difficult journey from Colfax to Virginia City due to a terrible storm.

entries.fullText:
- Reached Reno 11.30
- took stage at 1 P.M. to
Steamboat Springs thence
Stage Virginia City - terrible
mud & cold - arrived 7 P.M.
- Hotel - Mrs Baker
came - nothing from Mrs
Gordon - no letter or bills -
hence no appointment -
went home with Mrs. [B.?] -
slept with her - Mr G.
on lounge - Tired &
dreadfully disappointed -
the Cash fates all against
me - not a dollar sent home
since Nov 3d - 6 weeks of
hardest work and barely travelling expenses -
1000 miles travel & 37 speeches -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Virginia City, Nevada, but is disappointed to find no letter or bills from Mrs. Gordon and no appointment. She spends the night at Mrs. C. H. Baker's hotel.

entries.fullText:
Mrs C. H. Baker's
rain & mud & snow -
got no word from
Carson City - so did
not go down - the R.R.
is washed away - 22 miles -
Miss H. K. Clapp -
Principal Ladies Seminary
Carson City - Nevada
Ms. Higgins &
Mrs Calvin
Mr Tryon Fisher
Rev. T. McGrath
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony remains in Virginia City, Nevada, due to rain, mud, and snow. She receives no word from Carson City and does not go down. She lists several people she encountered.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Charlotte H. Baker
wife of E.G. Baker - a
Hard ware merchant -
Fine audience of 75
persons - $26 taken at door -
- the most terrific
storm of years - snow
& mud frozen - but wind a
perfect tornado -
made good speech -
- Mrs. Baker says the best
she ever heard - rather
high compliment - when she
was & is perfectly captivated
with Mrs Stanton -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Charlotte H. Baker gave a speech to a fine audience of 75 people in Virginia City, Nevada despite the most terrific storm of years.

entries.fullText:
Snow fell one foot in night -
Still at Virginia City -
Mr Baker came saying be
ready for stage in 15 minutes
but they simply took mails -
snowed all the forenoon
- Got things on for stage
at 10 A.M. - it went off without
me - and at night learned
another went at 4 P.M. - went
to Wells Fargo office - & booked
name for 8 tomorrow
A.M. - commenced
snowing again in evening -
dreadfully disappointed
fear Gordon & Sargents
will pass on ahead of
me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was still in Virginia City, where it snowed one foot overnight. She missed the stage and was afraid that Gordon and Sargents would pass ahead of her.

entries.fullText:
Up at 7 A.M. took
breakfast alone in French
Restaurant - at 9.30 the stage
called - took me to Wells Fargo
Office & then the agent
produced telegram that
road was impassible
so was taken back to
Mrs Bakers again -
snowed till after noon -
read Harpers Monthly - Jan
1872 - "Mrs Siddons" & "A
cup of coffee" - & listened
to Mrs B's essays on Geology
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is stuck in Virginia City due to impassable roads and spends the day reading and listening to essays on Geology.

entries.fullText:
Left Virginia City
at 10 A.M. - bright sun
shine - cold & severe
wind - six horse sleigh
six miles - terrific snow
drifts - then wheels to
Steamboat Springs & cars
there to Reno. - here all
warm & ground bare -
